commit_message:
Spec to accompany systems-monitoring blueprint

Change-Id: Ia37bf0d053ff44710a0c2af922ba459cd39d8b8d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-specs refs/changes/50/91750/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Systems Monitorin (CPU/RAM/etc) for TripleO Deployments ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/tripleo/+spec/tripleo-systems-monitoring A common method using TripleO Image Elements to install and configure a simple monitoring solution for TripleO-deployed Openstack installations. Based on Icinga and Check_MK, the system should automatically configure itself from heat and nova and checks should be automatically added from other elements. Problem description =================== At present, the TripleO community does not have a defined way to monitor and confirm that a stack continues to perform as expected once it is deployed. Heat and Nova API calls can tell you if the stack deployed successfully and whether or not the nodes are up, however they cannot tell you the current running state of the system. We need to provide a solution to this issue that provides alerting for at least the following: * Disk Usage * Memory Usage * Physical Network Interface status (i.e. "what is happening *under* Neutron?") * Service status * Apache * Process is Running * Listening on port 80 * Responding to requests * MySQL * Process is Running * Listening on port 3306 * Responding to requests * RabbitMQ * Process is Running * Listening on appropriate ports * Responding to requests * Queue Lengths are within desired parameters Proposed change =============== The proposed solution uses the following technologies: * Icinga (http://icinga.org/) * Check_MK (http://mathias-kettner.com/check_mk.html) Icinga provides the alerting framework and web interface for this platform, with check_mk providing the agents for running and reporting checks back to a central server. Check_MK is known to scale to over 2,000 hosts or 50,000 service checks for a single installation based on the listings at http://mathias-kettner.com/check_mk_monitoring_appliance.html and should therefore be more than suitable for a basic tripleo deployment. The choice of Icinga means that in future, we can implement a large number of other features such as automatic report generation via JasperReports (http://community.jaspersoft.com/), Business Process Logic (Check the Nova API, MySQL, Libvirt across all compute nodes and based on the output of those checks alert on availabilty of Nova as a service) and the ability to upgrade to Icinga2 via mk_livestatus (http://mathias-kettner.com/checkmk_livestatus.html). Alternatives ------------ Alternatives include Nagios, Sensu, Shinken, Riemann and many more and all these solutions rely on a centralised infrastructure of some sort just like icinga. Sensu and Riemann rely on a "push" infrastructure that potentially involves writing many small scripts to send checks and check results back to the server via some kind of transport. In the case of Sensu, this would require one RabbitMQ queue per check-type. Nagios, Shinken and Icinga have the ability to both pull and accept push checks from the various monitoring daemons that they run. Check_MK works around the contention issues that are often associated with Nagios and the traditional nagios->nrpe->check_script configuration, allowing many more checks per node than a traditional Niagios/Icinga setup without the need for adding message queues or addtional transport protocols. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None - Icinga Web can provide a REST/JSON API, however this is not to be integrated with any OpenStack APIs at this time. Security impact --------------- The monitoring node requires a username and password capable of running "nova list" against the api server. This file is generated from Heat and is owned by root with the permissions 750 Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- Adds a new website at "/icinga" on the node that has the icinga-cgi element deployed. Performance Impact ------------------ None expected. Other deployer impact --------------------- None expected Developer impact ---------------- There will be the ability to add checks for services to the check_mk_checks directory in your image element which will result in those checks being deployed to the appropriate node. Documentation on how to write a check will be added to the wiki if this blueprint is approved. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: macdomat (Matthew Macdonald-Wallace) Work Items ---------- Check_mk_agent Element (DONE and MERGED) Check_mk_server Element (NOT MERGED: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/87226/) icinga-cgi Element (NOT MERGED: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/87223/) Auto-collect checks (NOT MERGED: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/91324/) Icinga-Web Element (NOT STARTED) Nagios Business Process Addons Element (NOT STARTED) JasperReports Element (NOT STARTED) JasperReports/Icinga-Web Integration (NOT STARTED) Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unknown at present Documentation Impact ==================== Documentation will need to be added to show how to integrate Icinga etc. however I envisage most of this being links to existing 3rd-party docs. References ========== All inline above

commit_message:
Re-assert System State

This spec sets out a methodology to ensure that any changes made
to system state outside of HEAT are overwritten with the correct
configuration from HEAT.

Change-Id: I983bb3e4b064699f768aaa37375044777322d45d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-specs refs/changes/24/104524/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Re-assert System State ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/tripleo/+spec/re-assert-system-state At present we do not have a way to re-assert system state in the manner of other configuration management tooling to ensure that changes made outside of HEAT/Tripleo Image Elements are reset to the appropriate value. This blueprint aims to address this issue through the provision of a method for regularly re-asserting system state across the stack. Problem Description =================== OS-Refresh-Config and OS-Apply-Config work very well for "one-shot" configuration and for ensuring that modifications to the HEAT template are propagated throughout the stack, however they do not currently cover the following use cases: * A systems administrator logs on to a node in the stack and makes a direct modification to a configuration file that should be under the control of HEAT in order to fix a production issue. He intends to make the change permanent in future however needs to make it *now* in order to ensure business continuity. The change is never backported to HEAT, and the configuration is not changed in HEAT leaving a single node in the stack out of sync with the others. * A developer logs on to a node and enables DEBUG for the Nova compute service in order to try and fix a problem. The issue is resolved however DEBUG is not disabled. The HEAT template is not updated therefore the configuration is not refreshed and the much larger log files fill the disk taking the node off-line. Proposed Change =============== We need a mechanism to ensure that each time os-refresh-config runs the files to be managed on disk are compared to a "known good" rendered template. This could be as trivial as computing the SHA1 of the file on disk and the rendered template and if they fail to match the rendered template is copied in place of the file on disk. Once the file has been overwritten by os-refresh-config, we need a way to trigger a restart of any services affected by the change. The suggestion on the mailing list [0] was to set an environment variable that can then be referenced in element scripts to restart services if (and only if) the configuration changes. Alternatives ------------ One alternative approach would be to overwrite the file on disk with the rendered template every time os-refresh-config runs and restart all the services, however this would be incredibly inefficient and will lead to instability in the service as a whole. Security Impact --------------- Unknown Other End User Impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ There may be an incredibly small impact on the performance of the system each time the configuration is checksummed and whenever a service requires a restart, however this is no less of an impact than when a configuration change would be made via HEAT. The intention is to allow for a customisable time delay between runs with a default of 15 minutes. Other Deployer Impact --------------------- Not yet known Developer Impact ---------------- Some tripleo-image-element scripts will need refactoring to support this, the exact number is currently unknown. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: macdomat Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- * Add the ability to checksum the rendered template *before* it is applied to os-collect-config * Add the ability to checksum the current file on disk to os-collect-config * Add the logic to only replace the file on disk with the rendered template if the check sum does not match * Add version awareness to os-collect-config * Add version awareness to all os-refresh-config scripts that do disruptive things. * Add periodic command run to os-collect-config * Modify os-svc-enable to restart services if the environment variable is set Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= I'm not too sure how this would be tested at present, as it would involve making a change to the system external to heat and then logging in to confirm it had been overwritten - I'm open to suggestions on a "nice" way to do this? Documentation Impact ==================== Updates will be needed to any TripleO element documentation/guidance to add about only restarting services when config changes. References ========== [0] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2014-June/038798.html

commit_message:
XenServer: Fix initramfs scripts

During bashate -ing some files with .sh extension has been modified,
which are interpreted with /bin/sh, which takes a different syntax.
Fixing the issue:
    - rename the files, so they are not picked up
    - use syntax that's understood by sh

Change-Id: I617b24813df86687ca33745d0c940b0c659f2e14

commit_message:
vmware-split-backend-logic

Specification of the plan for moving backend logic from the VMware
plugin into a separate module.

Change-Id: If39f119b37c55ecfef0d016226b7245fdcfe190d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/17/104417/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is liceinsed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ====================================================== VMware: move network backend logic out of plugin code ====================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/meh-meh-meh The NSX plugin has both logic for managing the Neutron DB and logic for preparing NSX backend requests and handling responses. Splitting backend handling from API request processing will have several benefits, mainly for plugin code maintanability and ability to guarantee consistency between the neutron DB and the backend. Problem description =================== Request processing in the NSX plugin usually follows this pattern: * Request validation with additional NSX-specific checks * Backend operation on NSX (raise on failure - no modification on DB) * Neutron DB operation (raise on failure - DB transaction rolled back, NSX resources not always rolled back) * Prepare response and return While this usually works fine, this pattern has a few drawbacks: * With the current operation pattern it is possible to end up in situations where backend operations and DB operations are interleaved, possibly causing long DB transaction because of backend operations, which might ultimately result in DB errors. * With the current pattern it is difficult to handle properly backend failures in order to ensure consistency with the DB, as this will make plugin code more convoluted. * Some API operations actually coordinate one or more backend operations (see add_router_interface for an example). With the current pattern the methods implementing these operations bloat and become hard to maintain. * This kind of pattern causes the plugin module size to bloat. This is not ideal from a maintanability perspective. * In some cases the plugins ends up doing validation twice - before the backend operation and in the DB operation when calling the backend class. Validation in most cases involves fetching data from the DB, so this should possibly be avoided. Proposed change =============== The aim of this blueprint is to split neutron DB processing from backend handling, thus moving all the backend specific code outside of the plugin module. At a very high level, the workflow for a Neutron API request served by the NSX plugin will look like the following: [DIAGRAM MUST GO HERE] This change will bring the following benefits: * Maintanability: the size of the neutron VMware NSX plugin will considerably decrease. All backend-specific logic will be in a self-contained module. * Testability: backend handlers can be easily mocked. * Data consistency: the backend-specific logic will provide handlers which will ensure the backend status always matches the desired confgiuration, that is to say the one stored in the Neutron DB. * Efficiency: since there will be no more duplicate data validation. This is a self-contained activity which will decouple database operations in the Neutron DB from backend processing. By deferring backend processing to appropriate handler modules it will pave the say for supporting different request processing styles (e.g.: asynchronous) or other VMware backends with different API frontends. Alternatives ------------ There is no real alternative to this work - at least in the terms proposed in the previous section. However, similar results might be achieved with different approaches. From a certain perspective, what is being described here matches the mechanism driver model in the ML2 plugin. On the other hand, a ML2 mechanism driver is not a viable solution for the NSX backend. Amount of code churn, backward compatibility, and plugin extension support are only few of the reasons for which this would not be possible. Even if it would have been possible to preserve the behaviour of updating the Neutron DB only if the backend operation was successful, thus avoding the need for a DB rollback, this approach would not work very well with asynchronous request handlers. Moreover, some operations will require anyway duplicate validation logic. Data model impact ----------------- No DB model change foreseen for the scope of this blueprint. REST API impact --------------- Some exception messages might change because backend failures will now be handled by the dedicated handlers. This is backward compatible as the response codes won't change anyway. Security impact --------------- Almost none. Improved error handling in the backend handler module will ensure no sensitive internal information is disclosed through API error messages. Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ The DB rollback operations adds some overhead in case of failed operations. However, this should be negligible if one considers the percentage of operations which fail because of backend failures. On the other hand avoiding duplicate checks will increase the speed of some operations. Other deployer impact --------------------- As a part of this blueprint a config option specifying the particular backend used by the plugin might be introduced. However such config option will be for future proofing only and limited to a single backend handler for the scope of this blueprint. Developer impact ---------------- As a part of this blueprint the exception raised when a resource is not found on the backend will change. Current value: neutron.common.exceptions.NotFound New value: neutron.plugins.vmware.api_client.exception.ResourceNotFound Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: salvatore-orlando Work Items ---------- * Preliminary yak shaving. The minimum amount of code framework needed for supporting backend request handlers. * Handlers for network operations * Handlers for port and subnet operations * Handlers for security group operations * Handlers for router operations * Handlers for floating IP operations * Handler for managing DHCP and metadata access Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Plugin-level unit tests will be changed and greatly simplied by mocking the backend handlers. This will avoid using the fake API client. Unit tests for handlers will be added to ensure adequate code coverage. VMware specific tempest tests might be proposed. Such tests might or might not be merged in the main tempest branch (this depends on whether tempest core team is willing to accept tests that will never run on the upstream gate). However these test will run in the VMware minesweeper suite and validate correct backend behaviour. Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== None

subject: Make RequestContext use auth_token (not auth_tok)
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-10-28 15:47:51.000000000', 'files': ['glance/context.py', 'glance/tests/functional/db/base.py', 'glance/tests/unit/v1/test_registry_api.py', 'glance/api/middleware/context.py', 'glance/common/client.py', 'glance/tests/unit/common/test_client.py', 'glance/registry/client/v2/api.py', 'glance/registry/client/v1/api.py', 'glance/tests/functional/db/base_metadef.py', 'glance/image_cache/client.py', 'glance/tests/unit/test_context_middleware.py', 'glance/tests/utils.py', 'glance/scrubber.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/glance/commit/cc7ae2abd5c67b5573ca609e27c79d5c4f9a528d', 'message': 'Make RequestContext use auth_token (not auth_tok)

The RequestContext class from oslo-incubator uses 'auth_token'.
Glance's RequestContext uses 'auth_tok' -- which is inconsistent.

glance_store currently uses the oslo 'auth_token'.

We should not assume a 1-1 mapping from the glance_store to glance,
nor should we have glance_store support both 'auth_token' and
'auth_tok'. Therefore Glance should be updated to use 'auth_token'.

This change was generated automatically with:

$ for file in `find glance -name '*\.py' -exec grep -wl auth_tok "{}" \;` ; \
  do sed --in-place 's/\<auth_tok\>/auth_token/g' $file ; done

In addition, the set_auth_token function was removed. This had been used
by Nova to work around the auth_tok <-> auth_token inconsistency, but
was removed in mid-2012 as part of the move to python-glanceclient so
is no longer needed.

In conjuction with other changes this fixes image upload when
using the multi-tenant Swift store.

Change-Id: Ic8a5f44088990fd8f6290a5622b823f59ef365fc
Partial-bug: #1385213
'}]
commit_message:
Make RequestContext use auth_token (not auth_tok)

The RequestContext class from oslo-incubator uses 'auth_token'.
Glance's RequestContext uses 'auth_tok' -- which is inconsistent.

glance_store currently uses the oslo 'auth_token'.

We should not assume a 1-1 mapping from the glance_store to glance,
nor should we have glance_store support both 'auth_token' and
'auth_tok'. Therefore Glance should be updated to use 'auth_token'.

This change was generated automatically with:

$ for file in `find glance -name '*\.py' -exec grep -wl auth_tok "{}" \;` ; \
  do sed --in-place 's/\<auth_tok\>/auth_token/g' $file ; done

In addition, the set_auth_token function was removed. This had been used
by Nova to work around the auth_tok <-> auth_token inconsistency, but
was removed in mid-2012 as part of the move to python-glanceclient so
is no longer needed.

In conjuction with other changes this fixes image upload when
using the multi-tenant Swift store.

Change-Id: Ic8a5f44088990fd8f6290a5622b823f59ef365fc
Partial-bug: #1385213
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance refs/changes/78/131478/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: admin_token = self.registry.auth_token auth_token=admin_token) auth_token = self.registry.auth_token auth_token=auth_token)
deleted_lines: admin_token = self.registry.auth_tok auth_tok=admin_token) auth_token = self.registry.auth_tok auth_tok=auth_token)

commit_message:
Remove unused py33 tox env

It's apparent that Nova is quite a ways from Py3K support, and
developers are not expected to run the py33 tox env. Rather than add
more envs for later Python interpreter versions which will be
equally broken, just remove it for now.

Change-Id: I885e6e8899f771cc52a2bf6282fd7bc1ed3083aa
(cherry picked from commit fd297c108aba920bf3de43c29843425884253857)

commit_message:
Add '--xxx' only argument type for client cli

Beside the command type "<client> --key=<value> <command>", there is
other type of command type "<client> --key <command>" for example
"keystone --insecure tenant-list". Add this command argument type
into consideration.

Change-Id: I6bb97279ef380eb71ac581f8cd99623ab7d1519e

commit_message:
Fix glance_image for local images

When trying to upload an image from the local file system, the
resource provider was failing. Fixing it to use the --file option
for the glance client instead of going through stdin.

Change-Id: Ic6bade025d28e2eb33f86c2d4421b65d06e8274c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-glance refs/changes/13/132813/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: location = "--file=#{resource[:source]}" results = auth_glance('image-create', "--name=#{resource[:name]}", "--is-public=#{resource[:is_public]}", "--container-format=#{resource[:container_format]}", "--disk-format=#{resource[:disk_format]}", location)
deleted_lines: stdin = nil location = "< #{resource[:source]}" stdin = true if stdin result = auth_glance_stdin('image-create', "--name=#{resource[:name]}", "--is-public=#{resource[:is_public]}", "--container-format=#{resource[:container_format]}", "--disk-format=#{resource[:disk_format]}", location) else results = auth_glance('image-create', "--name=#{resource[:name]}", "--is-public=#{resource[:is_public]}", "--container-format=#{resource[:container_format]}", "--disk-format=#{resource[:disk_format]}", location) end

commit_message:
Reuse addresses from dhcp pool when possible

We can get rid from static pool, by reusing dhcp
address, assigned to node initially.

General procedure for assignment of ip addresses
is not changed, but i've added one more condition
to check if ip address is in range of admin_net.ip_range
if it is - it will be reused when creating ip address
if not - address will be used from pool, it will guarantee
that patch works on upgraded environments

Also made refactoring of old code

DocImpact
Closes-Bug: 1271571
Implments: blueprint get-gid-of-splitted-fueladmin-network

added_lines: def reusable_ip_address(cls, node, network): """Verifies that ip belongs to network and creates IPAddr in case it did :param node: Node database object. :param network: Network database object. :returns: IPAddr object or None """ if node.ip and cls.check_ip_belongs_to_net(node.ip, network): return IPAddr(node=node.id, ip_addr=node.ip, network=network.id) return None @classmethod # verification that node.ip (which is reported by agent) belongs # to one of the ranges of required to be able to reuse admin ip address # also such approach is backward compatible reusable_ip = cls.reusable_ip_address(node, admin_net) if reusable_ip: db().add(reusable_ip) else: nodes_need_ips.append(node_id) db().flush() free_ips = cls.get_free_ips(admin_net, len(nodes_need_ips)) free_ips = cls.get_free_ips(network, len(nodes_need_ips)) vip = cls.get_free_ips(network)[0] def is_ip_usable(cls, network_group, ip): return (ip != network_group.gateway and db().query(IPAddr).filter_by(ip_addr=ip).first() is None) @classmethod for ip_range in network_group.ip_ranges: for ip in IPRange(ip_range.first, ip_range.last): if cls.is_ip_usable(network_group, str(ip)): yield str(ip) def get_free_ips(cls, network_group, num=1): free_ips = list(islice(cls._iter_free_ips(network_group), 0, num))
deleted_lines: nodes_need_ips.append(node_id) free_ips = cls.get_free_ips(admin_net.id, len(nodes_need_ips)) free_ips = cls.get_free_ips(network.id, len(nodes_need_ips)) vip = cls.get_free_ips(network.id)[0] def _chunked_range(cls, iterable, chunksize=64): """We want to be able to iterate over iterable chunk by chunk. We instantiate iter object from itarable. We then yield iter instance slice in infinite loop. Iter slice starts from the last used position and finishes on the position which is offset with chunksize from the last used position. :param iterable: Iterable object. :type iterable: iterable :param chunksize: Size of chunk to iterate through. :type chunksize: int :yields: iterator :raises: StopIteration """ it = iter(iterable) while True: s = islice(it, chunksize) # Here we check if iterator is not empty calling # next() method which raises StopInteration if # iter is empty. If iter is not empty we yield # iterator which is concatenation of fisrt element in # slice and the ramained elements. yield chain([s.next()], s) @classmethod for ip_addr in ifilter( lambda ip: db().query(IPAddr).filter_by( ip_addr=str(ip) ).first() is None and not str(ip) == network_group.gateway, chain(*[ IPRange(ir.first, ir.last) for ir in network_group.ip_ranges ]) ): yield ip_addr def get_free_ips(cls, network_group_id, num=1): ng = db().query(NetworkGroup).get(network_group_id) free_ips = [] for ip in cls._iter_free_ips(ng): free_ips.append(str(ip)) if len(free_ips) == num: break

Improve documentation of run_tests.sh script

Fix typos and change a few sentences of run_tests.sh script.
Also insert punctuation marks in several sentences of help message
to keep a pattern.

commit_message:
enable patch ports when availble for connecting openvswitch bridges

Change-Id: I665cd6628973f84b40b4ef24d1e1319359dd2306
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/83/96183/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =================================================================== Open vSwitch to use patch ports in place of veth pairs for vlan n/w =================================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/openvswitch-patch-port-use The current implementation for connecting openvswtich bridges is via veth pairs when when not using vxlan or gre tunnels. This blueprint proposes the use of openvswitch patch-ports for local, flat and vlan deployments. A fall back to veth pairs shall be implemented in the eventuality patch-ports are not supported. * changes to neutron/plugins/openvswitch/agent/ovs_neutron_agent.py Problem description =================== Intel(r) DPDK accelerated vSwitch currently does not support veth pairs and patch ports are to be used in place. Proposed change =============== Enable the neutron agent to attach the integration and physical bridges together with patch ports Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Patch ports themselves should not propose any more security concerns; they are already used when useing GRE tunnles for example Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ Some network performance increase as the packets are not copied between bridges. Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: david-mahony Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- and integration bridges. * fall back to veth pairs when patch ports are not available. * add unit tests Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Add unit test to test patch ports. Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== None

commit_message:
OFAgent: Simplify bridge setup

Change-Id: Idd70e8feb49abf155e2d3d5c9e1d9c1e719dd63f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/34/130134/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================== OFAgent: Simplify bridge setup ============================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/ofagent-bridge-setup Problem Description =================== - ofagent uses bridge name (eg. "br-int") to specify the bridge to control. it's OVS-dependant. - ofagent automatically set up the bridge on startup. (i.e. add-br, set br protocols, set-controller, etc) there are little point to perform it every time an agent starts up. on-time setup during deployment is enough. also, it's OVS-dependant. Proposed Change =============== - use datapath-id instead of bridge name. introduce a new config option to specify the bridge using datapath-id. make it an alternative of "integration_bridge" option. - remove code to set up the bridge from ofagent. document the instruction to set up the bridge instead. - adapt devstack accordingly. - retire "integration_bridge" option for ofagent later. (probably in "L" cycle.) Alternatives ------------ instead of datapath-id, OFPMP_DESC might be usable to distinguish bridge. OVS by default doesn't provide useful description though. Data Model Impact ----------------- none REST API Impact --------------- none Security Impact --------------- none Notifications Impact -------------------- none Other End User Impact --------------------- none Performance Impact ------------------ none Other Deployer Impact --------------------- a deployer needs to update his config. Developer Impact ---------------- none Community Impact ---------------- none Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: yamamoto Other contributors: kakuma Work Items ---------- see "Proposed Change" section. Dependencies ============ none Testing ======= update the existing tests if necessary. Tempest Tests ------------- none Functional Tests ---------------- none API Tests --------- none Documentation Impact ==================== User Documentation ------------------ the new option and upgrade instruction need to be documented. Developer Documentation ----------------------- none References ========== none

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-10-29 02:19:02.000000000', 'files': ['specs/template.rst'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs/commit/9d74fe4868de50dd0c40d20e7b8e5764f7bc186e', 'message': 'Add requirement for APIImpact flag

Adds a requirement for an APIImpact flag in

commit_message:
Add requirement for APIImpact flag

Adds a requirement for an APIImpact flag in
the commit message for a proposed spec if it proposes
changes to the Neutron REST API. This will make it
much easier for people such as the API WG who want to
review API changes across OpenStack to find and
review proposed API changes.

Change-Id: I21f1b9c645bd40b8c1f2e5e627c4dd5a667431dc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/23/131623/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: If your specification proposes any changes to the Neutron REST API such as changing parameters which can be returned or accepted, or even the semantics of what happens when a client calls into the API, then you should add the APIImpact flag to the commit message. Specifications with the APIImpact flag can be found with the following query:: https://review.openstack.org/#/q/status:open+project:openstack/neutron-specs+message:apiimpact,n,z

commit_message:
Add Guru Meditation Report Functionality to Neutron

Change-Id: Iaff6d14dfcdbc1e343f802fbe1f03b09a8754467
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/78/131678/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =================================================== Add Guru Meditation Report Functionality to Neutron =================================================== Guru Meditation Report functionality has been implemented in Oslo. The trigger code now needs to be added to the Neutron executables so that they print a GMR on SIGUSR1 (see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GuruMeditationReport) Problem Description =================== GMR can help debugging neutron by provider lots of process running status, including configuration, native thread stack trace and greenlet stack trace. GMR can be triggered by sending USR1 signal to neutron process, if the process is a daemon, the report will be placed inside logdir, otherwise the report will output to the console. GMR will be supported by following components: * neutron-service * ml2-agent * dhcp-agent * l3-agent (vpn-agent) * l3-metadata-proxy Proposed Change =============== GMR has already been implemented in olso-incubator, pick GMR from olso and add trigger code. Data Model Impact ----------------- None. REST API Impact --------------- None. Security Impact --------------- The configuration can be viewed by the user who can read logdir. Notifications Impact -------------------- None. Other End User Impact --------------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ None. Other Deployer Impact --------------------- None. Developer Impact ---------------- None. Community Impact ---------------- None. Alternatives ------------ None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Zang MingJie <zealot0630@gmail.com> Work Items ---------- * Sync GRM from olso * Add trigger code Dependencies ============ None. Testing ======= Tempest Tests ------------- None. Functional Tests ---------------- * Test correct report can be generated. API Tests --------- None. Documentation Impact ==================== None. User Documentation ------------------ None. Developer Documentation ----------------------- None. References ========== * Guru Meditation Report: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GuruMeditationReport * GMR in Nova: http://docs.openstack.org/developer/nova/devref/gmr.html

added_lines: #!/bin/bash # Copyright 2014 Mirantis, Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. # This script will rebuild local ubuntu mirror. # Based on the method described here: # http://troubleshootingrange.blogspot.com/2012/09/hosting-simple-apt-repository-on-centos.html # Example: # regenerate_ubuntu_repo /path/to/ubuntu/repo precise REPO_PATH=$1 REPONAME=$2 BINDIR=${REPO_PATH}/dists/${REPONAME}/main binoverride=indices/override.${REPONAME}.main extraoverride=indices/override.${REPONAME}.extra.main package_deb=${BINDIR}/binary-amd64/Packages release_header=`head -8 ${REPO_PATH}/dists/${REPONAME}/Release` cd ${REPO_PATH} echo "Regenerating Ubuntu local mirror..." # Scan *.deb packages dpkg-scanpackages -m --extra-override ${extraoverride} -a amd64 pool/main ${binoverride} > $package_deb 2>/dev/null gzip -9c $package_deb > ${package_deb}.gz # Generate release file cd ${REPO_PATH}/dists/${REPONAME} echo "$release_header" > Release # Generate hashes c1=(MD5Sum: SHA1: SHA256: SHA512:) c2=(md5 sha1 sha256 sha512) i=0 while [ $i -lt ${#c1[*]} ]; do echo ${c1[i]} >> Release for hashme in `find main -type f \( -name "Package*" -o -name "Release*" \)`; do chash=`openssl dgst -${c2[$i]} ${hashme}|cut -d" " -f 2` size=`stat -c %s ${hashme}` echo " ${chash} ${size} ${hashme}" >> Release done i=$(( $i + 1)); done

commit_message:
fuel_upgrade: add hack to make repo symlink

We need to add next symlink

    repo/ubuntu/x86_64 -> repo/ubuntu/fuelweb/x86_64

in order to get working upgrade to 6.0, because in 6.0 we know nothing
about 'fuelweb' folder in repo struct, but we have it in old repos from
previous installation.

Change-Id: I7985a1f64b54bfff84df7098252448ea6ec6b613
Closes-Bug: #1390521

commit_message:
Save fuel_version field for plugins model

It's important to keep all of the information
which plugin provides about dependencies.
In the future versions there might be cases
when we have to write some workaround not to
brake old plugins.

Change-Id: Id0f45def2972a60040e3a1d2a016a1ed46a05ed3
Implements: blueprint cinder-neutron-plugins-in-fuel

commit_message:
Print error message if one of containers failed

Show an error message if one or more containers failed to pass
"dockerctl check" tests.

Related-bug: #1390129

Change-Id: I3dba31a06fa161ba935948456488e899cfdc3e00
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-main refs/changes/10/133410/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: rc=$?if [ "$rc" == "0" ] ; then echo "Fuel node deployment complete!" else echo "ERROR: One or more containers failed to pass tests! Please check logs." fi

commit_message:
NetApp fix attach fail for already mapped volume

This patch fixes the error raised during mapping of a volume
to the host during attach operation if the volume is already
mapped to the host.

Change-Id: I4f711e7ac18eea0dfddab65fd85a3601fe967a88
Closes-bug: #1310659
(cherry picked from commit dcec1b84f4d3462fc408f4152f4c89b8df79d629)

commit_message:
Fix KeyError in md_utils in fuel-agent

fuel-agent failed after reset cluster and re-deploy while creating
new md device if inactive devices were found

Change-Id: I38f086fae7e7c5cd2a62669509538e8ddbb092b2
Closes-Bug: #1390492

commit_message:
Extract version definition to a separate file

Before, version was stores in the init file.
It's better not to store such kind of public data
as version to init file.
Moreover, whole murano package needed to be imported to identify project version
Now, separate file is used for that

Also, doc builder config was updated to support this change

Change-Id: Iede1dfbe9ae4d8c6fb5ecdeb8f8f25124e4bc34f

commit_message:
Fix traceback on rare agent error case

If self._deploy_is_done() fails for any reason when called on a agent
heartbeat, 'msg' was not set, creating a traceback when trying to log
it. Let's set a default.

Co-Authored-By: Jim Rollenhagen <jim@jimrollenhagen.com>

Change-Id: I7399821019bab4e3cf08324ee3314c40467e00a4

commit_message:
Add cinder actions

 * Mistral now includes all Cinder actions
 * Unit tests

Change-Id: Ia663df09ae15f8154d49bbf232118617f92cba30

added_lines: # Copyright 2014 - Mirantis, Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); # you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. # You may obtain a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, # WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. # See the License for the specific language governing permissions and # limitations under the License. from mistral.actions.openstack.action_generator import generators from mistral.actions.openstack import actions from mistral.tests import base class CinderGeneratorTest(base.BaseTest): def test_generator(self): action_name = "cinder.volumes_list" generator = generators.CinderActionGenerator action_classes = generator.create_actions() action = self._assert_single_item( action_classes, name=action_name ) self.assertIsNotNone(generator) self.assertTrue(issubclass(action['class'], actions.CinderAction)) self.assertEqual("volumes.list", action['class'].client_method_name)

Refactor CLI tests

- tearDown logic was updated. Now we collect all test items and then
delete only them.

Closes-Bug: #1386804

Change-Id: I95193ad89d7db44c100b93cec7bf0c1d3db23209

subject: Allow to add router interface to IPv6 SLAAC network
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-10-21 10:24:26.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/bedd762b02c973dca605fb9bfafbc09d4ffc12c1', 'message': 'Cannot add router interface to IPv6 SLAAC network

Neutron should allow an IPv6 subnet configured with SLAAC
(or dhcpv6-stateless) to be attached to a router interface.
Currently this is broken, this patch fixes the issue.

Details of the fix (will remove this message and add testcases
after receiving some review comments).
Neutron allocates the gateway_ip (if not specified) to the first IP address
in the subnet CIDR and the gateway_ip is stored as part of subnet details.
So, by the time the request to attach the subnet gateway to the router is
received, the gateway_ip is already allocated/reserved in the subnet.

For this particular bug, there are two cases to consider...
1. When the gateway_ip is not specified as part of subnet creation.
2. Gateway_ip is specified and is part of subnet CIDR.

For the first case, IMO it would be ideal if Neutron does not reserve
any gateway_ip address in create_subnet and allocate (based on EUI-64
addressing - as MAC address is allocated only during port creation)
it only when the request to attach to the router interface is seen.
On the other hand, if the user creates the subnet with gateway_ip which
is part of subnet CIDR, we can modify Neutron to check the port owner
and if it happens to be the router, accept it.

Closes-Bug: #1382076
Change-Id: If0c48a7287a828eef4a0f0b0859d4f898d2937bd
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-10-22 20:54:38.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/d9620218631e23e22b75d96f223fdf68bc2339bc', 'message': 'Cannot add router interface to IPv6 SLAAC network

commit_message:
Allow to add router interface to IPv6 SLAAC network

This patch will allow an IPv6 subnet configured with SLAAC
(or dhcpv6-stateless) to be attached to a router interface.

Closes-Bug: #1382076
Change-Id: If0c48a7287a828eef4a0f0b0859d4f898d2937bd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/65/129865/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _subnet_uses_eui64(s): """Check if ipv6 address will be calculated via EUI64.""" return (s['ipv6_address_mode'] == l3_constants.IPV6_SLAAC or s['ipv6_address_mode'] == l3_constants.DHCPV6_STATELESS) if not subnet['gateway_ip'] and not self._subnet_uses_eui64(subnet): if subnet['gateway_ip']: fixed_ip = {'ip_address': subnet['gateway_ip'], 'subnet_id': subnet['id']} else: fixed_ip = {'subnet_id': subnet['id']}
deleted_lines: if not subnet['gateway_ip']: fixed_ip = {'ip_address': subnet['gateway_ip'], 'subnet_id': subnet['id']}

commit_message:
Change default network tenant

- Internal and external network tenants should
  be changed according to stored in cluster attributes

Closes-Bug: 1376515
(cherry picked from commit 5cfdc92fcab29b91e8bc4c58212aa16e0e028a93)

commit_message:
Fix missing keyboard focus from Console's iframe

The iframe in Instance Console doesn't get focus on loading, so the user
cannot type into the console, this change is focusing for console iframe
on loading

Closes-Bug: #1389117
Change-Id: Idfb731c9a00506ad4d29174d92476d10316de05c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/75/132575/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: $('iframe#console_embed').css({ height: $(document).height() + 'px' }).focus();

commit_message:
Fix image-builder scripts

* Fix encoding issues
* Convert all files to UTF-8
* Fix indendation and hanging whitespaces
* Add new vairable LIBVIRT_IMAGES_DIR to be able to use faster drive for KVM images
* Fix unattended template for sysrep on Windows Server 2008 R2

Change-Id: Ifb4df8c0eeddf1698a6e4c691f48e92406bac770

commit_message:
Add a spec for reducing tarball size

Spec for the blueprint reduce-tarball-size

Change-Id: I2a35586d8abc484e6654eae97833b7637ab2613a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-specs refs/changes/91/121591/13 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================= Reduce upgrade tarball's size ============================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/fuel/+spec/reduce-tarball-size Let's reduce size of our fuel upgrade tarball, since it's huge and uncomfortable for distribution. Problem description =================== We need to reduce upgrade tarball's size in order to simplify distribution workflow, boost up downloading/unpacking speed and reduce used space on master node's file system. Proposed change =============== Since Fuel 5.1 an upgrade tarball may contain few OpenStack bundles and each OpenStack bundle includes a self-sufficient repo. The "self-sufficient" here means that the repo contains not only OpenStack packages, but system. The system packages are rarely changed so in most cases we can distribute within OpenStack bundle a small repo which contains only those packages that were changed regarding to some base previous release. To achieve this goal we need to resolve next points: * The Nailgun has to be able to send one, two or more repos to Astute and Astute has to be able to handle this. * Fuel-OSCI has to prepare special repos which will contain only packages that are changed regarding to some previous release. * The Fuel Upgrade script has to be able to add new "OpenStack releases" with one, two or more repos. Alternatives ------------ We can distribute just a set of changed packages instead of a small repo. In that case we will need to create a new repo on fly during fuel upgrade procedure. Creating repos on fly is not trivial procedure and may fail time to time due to outside factors. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Upgrade impact -------------- The Fuel Upgrade script has to be able to add new "OpenStack releases" with one, two or more repos. Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ An unpack time of tarball should be reduced. Other deployer impact --------------------- * slave nodes may have more than one repo in the system. Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: * Igor Kalnitsky <ikalnitsky@mirantis.com> Other contributors: * Fuel OSCI Work Items ---------- * add multi-repo support to both Astute and Nailgun; * change uan pgrade tarball format to contain diff-based repos; * add support of diff-based repos to fuel-upgrade script. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Existing Fuel Upgrade / OpenStack patching tests are enough since it's about improvements, not about entirely new feature. But next tests may be added: * tests that there're more than one repo on slaves; * tests that an upgrade tarball contains only changed packages, not all. Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== * #fuel-dev on freenode

commit_message:
Common OpenStack Identity Resources

Implement common code for Keystone resources management.

Prereq for blueprint:common-openstack-identity-resource
Change-Id: I9e8e59e7d386188098e679cb2774182fffe6cf6d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-openstack-specs refs/changes/00/129700/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================== Common OpenStack Identity Resource ================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/puppet-openstacklib/+spec/commmon-openstack-identity-resource This spec proposes to introduce defined resource types in openstacklib to provide a common interface for setting up Keystone resources used by the major OpenStack services. The current modules for these services would use this interface rather than duplicating code across these modules. Problem description =================== Nearly all of the Puppet modules for OpenStack services set up Keystone users, roles, tenants and endpoints for themselves and most of them do this using nearly identical code. This causes a great deal of repetition across modules and will lead to inconsistencies. Proposed change =============== Abstract the identity functionality into defined resource types in the openstacklib module. This resource would implement the same functionality as the keystone::auth type already done in most of OpenStack modules. The new resource would use the newest identity modules. Alternatives ------------ The alternative to implementing this feature in openstacklib is to maintain the Keystone resources maganement functionality in each module separately. Data model impact ----------------- The OpenStack modules would be updated to depend to use the new identity resources to configure their respective Keystone resources. Some of current code in modules would have their current code replaced with a call to the new defined resource type in openstacklib. No new classes would be needed for these modules, except for heat which would need to have a postgresql subclass added. Module API impact ----------------- * New defined resource type: openstacklib::identity * Parameters for openstacklib::identity: password : Password to create for the service user; string; required auth_name : The name of the service user; string; optional; default to the $title of the resource, i.e. 'nova' service_name : Name of the service; string; required public_address : Public endpoint; string; optional: default to '127.0.0.1' admin_address : Admin endpoint; string; optional: default to '127.0.0.1' internal_address : Public endpoint; string; optional: default to '127.0.0.1' public_proto : Public endpoint proto; string; optional: default to 'http' admin_proto : Admin endpoint proto; string; optional: default to 'http' internal_proto : Internal endpoint proto; string; optional: default to 'http' public_port : Endpoint port; string; required internal_port : Endpoint port; string; required admin_port : Endpoint port; string; required region : Endpoint region; string; optional: default to 'RegionOne' tenant : Service tenant; string; optional: default to 'services' email : Service email; string; optional: default to '$auth_name@localhost' configure_endpoint : Whether to create the endpoint. string; optional: default to True configure_user : Whether to create the user. string; optional: default to True configure_user_role : Whether to create the user role. string; optional: default to True * Example use case for openstacklib::identity: In ::nova::keystone::auth: ::openstacklib::identity { 'nova': password => 'secrete', auth_name => 'nova', service_name => 'compute', public_address => '11.0.0.1', admin_address => '192.168.0.1', internal_address => '10.0.0.1', admin_port => '8774', internal_port => '8774', public_port => '8774', notify => Service['nova-api'] } would create user, tenant, role and endpoint for OpenStack Compute API service and restart nova-api. End user impact --------------------- None aside from the API. Performance Impact ------------------ None Deployer impact --------------------- The user needs to install the openstacklib module prior to using the OpenStack modules. Developer impact ---------------- Changes to keystone setup will happen in the openstacklib module rather than in the individual OpenStack service modules. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: EmilienM Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- * Create new defined resource type in openstacklib. * Update ceilometer, cinder, glance, heat, keystone, neutron, and nova modules to depend on openstacklib and use the new resource. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unit test fixtures of all puppet modules would need to be updated to install openstacklib. Existing tests in these modules would be replicated in openstacklib. Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== None

commit_message:
Replace "nova" entries in iptables_manager with "neutron"

In iptables_manager docstrings there are still some references to
nova left from nova/network/linux_net.py.
Remove these references and update the docstrings.

Change-Id: I50813e3050f7f117512bde7c2563ce3410939e54
Closes-Bug: #1389601

added_lines: so if neutron-openvswitch creates a chain named 'OUTPUT', it'll actually end up being named 'neutron-openvswi-OUTPUT'. First, neutron-filter-top. It's added at the top of FORWARD and OUTPUT. Its name is not wrapped, so it's shared between the various neutron workers. It's intended for rules that need to live at the top of the FORWARD and OUTPUT chains. It's in both the ipv4 and ipv6 set of tables. # among the various neutron components. It sits at the very top # shared among the various neutron components. We set it as the # last chain of POSTROUTING chain.
deleted_lines: so if nova-compute creates a chain named 'OUTPUT', it'll actually end up named 'nova-compute-OUTPUT'. First, neutron-filter-top. It's added at the top of FORWARD and OUTPUT. Its name is not wrapped, so it's shared between the various nova workers. It's intended for rules that need to live at the top of the FORWARD and OUTPUT chains. It's in both the ipv4 and ipv6 set of tables. # among the various nova components. It sits at the very top # shared among the various nova components. We set it as the last # chain of POSTROUTING chain.

commit_message:
Remove ephemeral size assertion in baremetal scenario

The test currently fails if the the baremetal flavor has no
ephemeral disk set.  This removes an unnecessary assertion and
unblocks tests against environments that do not deploy ephemeral
disks.

Change-Id: I7f13d4d7b40ea8879eaa30a19c117aef284586ff

commit_message:
[WIP] Support incremental snapshot for instance

This specs descrbe BP incremental-instance-snapshot

Change-Id: I261dc674d8d98a45da5f95e4de1e707568ede398
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/06/106306/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Support incremental snapshot ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/incremental-instance-snapshot Currently nova support create snapshot for instance. For each snapshot, nova will take a full-copy of instance's image. The full-copy will waste a lot of network bandwidth and storage. This BP propose to support incremental snapshot of instance's image. Problem description =================== The full-copy snapshot isn't effcient. It waste more network bandwidth and storage. The user need waiting more time for snapshost instance. Proposed change =============== Nova REST API ------------- Add new paramenter 'incremental' for createImage API. 'incremental' is boolean. When 'incremental' is False, nova will take full-copy snapshot. When 'incremental' is True, nova will take incremental snapshot. Before doing incremental snapshot, the instance at least need a full-copy snapshot first. Incremental snapshot image -------------------------- Nova will add system_metadata 'last_snapshot_image_ref' to instance that indicates the parent image for next incremental snapshot. When doing incremental snapshot, nova add property 'parent_image_ref' to snapshot image with the value of instance's system_metadata 'last_snapshot_image_ref'. When booting instance with image, nova can check the image's property 'parent_image_ref', and then can find out all the parent image to combine them as a whole image. Libvirt incremental snapshot ---------------------------- This BP propose add incremental snapshot to libvirt driver. And only support 'qcow2' image first. The instance need to be create with qcow2 image, the snapshot image uploaded as qcow2 format too. Before doing the first time incremental snapshot, the images store in local storage as: base_image->active_image Then doing external snapshot. Then images looks like as below: base_image->active_image->snap1 Then the active_image is the incremental snapshot, nova will uploaded it into glance with property. For follow-up incremental snapshot, nova will doing external snapshot first. base_image->active_image->snap1->snap2 The snap1 is the incremental snapshot image, then upload it into glance image. For performance, nova need reduce the image chain, nova will commit snap1 into active_image, then images chain back to as below: base_image->active_image->snap2 snap1 become useless, nova will remove it. Libvirt boot instance with incremental snapshot image ----------------------------------------------------- When boot new instance, nova will check the 'parent_image_ref' property for image. If image has parent_image_ref, nova will try to download parent image. Nova will iterate the image chain, and rebase those images as order. Then commit then into one image. Alternatives ------------ * Incremental image Let glance support incremental image. From nova side, nova will only see one image, the image is combine by glance. With this way, glance need to implement combine image for different image type. This way is more complex. * Incremental snapshot with dirty map for qemu This way won't increase the image chain, that's pretty good for performance. But it didn't implement in qemu yet. After it implement, it also need waiting for libvirt support. So that will be long time. https://lists.gnu.org/archive/html/qemu-devel/2013-12/msg00152.html Data model impact ----------------- There isn't any DB model change. This propose utilize system_metadata to store last time snapshot. And glance image property to store the parent image for incremental snapshot image. REST API impact --------------- This propose add new paramenter 'incremental' to createImage action both for nova V2 and V3 REST API. For V2 API, the new extension 'os-incremental-snapshot'will be added for user can detection the new parameter enabled. For V3 API, the new parameter will be added directly. create_image = { 'type': 'object', 'properties': { 'create_image' { type: 'object', properties: { 'name': parameter_types.name, 'incremental': parameter_types.boolean, 'metadata': {'type': 'object'} } 'required': ['name'], 'additionalProperties': False, } } 'required': ['create_image'] 'additionalProperties': False, } If 'incremental' didn't specific, then the default value is 'False'. If 'incremental' is True, but instance haven't 'last_snapshot_image_ref' in system_metadata, API will return 400 (BadRequest). Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- The incremental snapshot will speed up the snapshot of instance. Performance Impact ------------------ After doing incremental snapshot, there will be one more level in image chain. That will affect the instance performance. After qemu support incremental back-up with dirty-map, the performance will be resolve. Other deployer impact --------------------- The incremental snapshot will reduce the network bandwidth and save more storage. Developer impact ---------------- The image chain changed after support incremental snapshot. Developer shouldn't suppose the image only have one level backing_file. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Alex Xu (xuhj@linux.vnet.ibm.com) Work Items ---------- * Add incremental snapshot for libvirt driver * Add new parameter for REST API [TODO...] Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= [TODO] Documentation Impact ==================== The API paramenter will be document. And doc how to do incremental snapshot in admin doc. References ========== None

has the smallest granularity available that covers the timespan

commit_message:
Extension for moving aggregation in API layer

Added extension for moving average, moving variance,
ewma. Unit tests added.

Query syntax (required parameter: window. optional: center,
resolution):

    GET /v1/entity/UUID/measures?aggregation=moving-average&
	window=30S&resolution=high
or
    GET /v1/entity/UUID/measures?aggregation=ewma&window=60S

The moving aggregates are performed on the rolled-up data
with granularity that factors into the window size. Resolution
'high' finds the finest granularity data; resolution 'low'
finds the coarsest granularity data. A 404 response code
is returned for invalid or missing parameters.

Change-Id: If40e58480f1512dd17b9c09cb75fd54c7193c257
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/gnocchi refs/changes/15/104415/30 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import pandas as pd import datetime import numpy as np #originally from stackoverflow.com/questions/15771472/pandas-rolling-\ #mean-by-time-interval solution by user2689410 #see also this post: stackoverflow.com/questions/14300768/pandas-rolling-\ #computation-with-window-based-on-values-instead-of-counts def rolling_mean(data, window, min_periods=1, center=False): ''' Function that computes a rolling mean Parameters ---------- :param data : DataFrame or Series If a DataFrame is passed, the rolling_mean is computed for all columns. :param window : int or string If int is passed, window is the number of observations used for calculating the statistic, as defined by the function pd.rolling_mean(). If a string is passed, it must be a frequency string, e.g. '90S'. This is internally converted into a DateOffset object, representing the window size. :param min_periods : int Minimum number of observations in window required to have a value. Returns ------- Series or DataFrame, if more than one column ''' def f(x): '''Function to apply that actually computes the rolling mean''' if center == False: dslice = col[x-pd.datetools.to_offset(window).delta:x] # adding a microsecond because when slicing with labels # start and endpoint are inclusive <-- taken out (atmalagon) else: dslice = col[x-pd.datetools.to_offset(window).delta/2: x+pd.datetools.to_offset(window).delta/2] if dslice.size < min_periods: return np.nan else: return dslice.mean() data = pd.DataFrame(data.copy()) dfout = pd.DataFrame() if isinstance(window, int): dfout = pd.rolling_mean(data, window, min_periods=min_periods, center=center) elif isinstance(window, basestring): idx = pd.Series(data.index.to_pydatetime(), index=data.index) for colname, col in data.iterkv(): result = idx.apply(f) result.name = colname dfout = dfout.join(result, how='outer') if dfout.columns.size == 1: dfout = dfout.ix[:,0] return dfout

commit_message:
allow image_id for imageRef in create volume API

This adds support for replacing the imageRef key with image_id when
creating a volume in both v1 and v2 of the Cinder API.

Closes-Bug: 1375867

Change-Id: I6770de8f70e00a3c8dc27ecf8dd88b3586b842ea

commit_message:
Add pool_id column to Domains Table

 This adds the pool_id column to the domains table
 along with the necessary code changes and tests as
 part of all the changes that need to be done to
 accomodate server pools

 Partially-implements: blueprint server-pools-storage

 - Migrate servers from servers table to
   poolattributes table
 - Remove all old server api code
 - Make changes to backends to use poolattribute
   nameservers instead of servers

Change-Id: I535a04cac27d1068398fd982ca14016c38cbd134

added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2014 Rackspace Hosting # # Author: Betsy Luzader <betsy.luzader@rackspace.com> # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from oslo.config import cfg from sqlalchemy.schema import Table, Column, MetaData from migrate.changeset.constraint import UniqueConstraint from designate.sqlalchemy.types import UUID meta = MetaData() def upgrade(migrate_engine): meta.bind = migrate_engine domains_table = Table('domains', meta, autoload=True) # Get the default pool_id from the config file default_pool_id = cfg.CONF['service:central'].default_pool_id # Create the pool_id column pool_id_column = Column('pool_id', UUID(), default=default_pool_id, nullable=True) pool_id_column.create(domains_table, populate_default=True) # Alter the table to drop default value after populating it domains_table.c.pool_id.alter(default=None) dialect = migrate_engine.url.get_dialect().name if dialect.startswith('sqlite'): # Add missing unique index constraint = UniqueConstraint('name', 'deleted', name='unique_domain_name', table=domains_table) constraint.create() def downgrade(migrate_engine): meta.bind = migrate_engine domains_table = Table('domains', meta, autoload=True) domains_table.c.pool_id.drop()

commit_message:
Added metadata lint and puppet-syntax gems

metadata-json-lint is a little tool to check the validity of
Puppet metatdata.json files.

puppet-syntax tool check the validity of templates,manifests and hiera
files (the goal here is to replace manual checks in the gate by a
standard? check `rake syntax`).

Change-Id: I60b9cdfe27eeb8a8f5ad3a238dd847ed3096cb6b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-ceilometer refs/changes/08/127608/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: gem 'metadata-json-lint' gem 'puppet-syntax'

commit_message:
Add doc for multiple backends configuration

Add doc for how to configure multiple backends in manila.conf.

Change-Id: Ida126a6d5915f5a3309128e56e8701a401444896
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/manila refs/changes/19/124519/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. Copyright (c) 2014 EMC Corporation All Rights Reserved. Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain a copy of the License at http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations under the License. Multi-backend configuration =========================== Here is an example of how multi-backend can be configured in `/etc/manila/manila.conf`: [DEFAULT] enabled_backends=backendA, backendB [backendA] emc_share_backend = vnx emc_nas_server = 1.1.1.1 emc_nas_password = password emc_nas_login = user emc_nas_server_container = server_2 emc_nas_pool_name = "Pool 1" share_driver = manila.share.drivers.emc.driver.EMCShareDriver [backendB] emc_share_backend = vnx emc_nas_server = 1.1.1.1 emc_nas_password = password emc_nas_login = user emc_nas_server_container = server_3 emc_nas_pool_name = "Pool 2" share_driver = manila.share.drivers.emc.driver.EMCShareDriver

commit_message:
Remove ZeroMQ installation

ZeroMQ is not necessary anymore for Storm. Without ZeroMQ the default
Netty is used for messaging.

Closes-bug: #1390446
Change-Id: Iff91dfc96d9644087f0b32c1ce694c20d9e14d3a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sahara-image-elements refs/changes/82/132882/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: cd $tmp_dir echo "Installing ZeroMQ" wget http://download.zeromq.org/zeromq-2.1.7.tar.gz tar -xzf zeromq-2.1.7.tar.gz cd zeromq-2.1.7 ./configure make make install cd .. echo "Installing JZMQ" git clone https://github.com/nathanmarz/jzmq.git cd jzmq/src touch classdist_noinst.stamp CLASSPATH=.:./.:$CLASSPATH javac -d . org/zeromq/ZMQ.java org/zeromq/ZMQException.java org/zeromq/ZMQQueue.java org/zeromq/ZMQForwarder.java org/zeromq/ZMQStreamer.java cd .. cd $tmp_dir/jzmq ./autogen.sh ./configure make make install

revisions:

'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-11-07 15:24:05.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/requirements/commit/e0bdf929f2811b919950526887ae0f0a779fd2aa', 'message': 'Add cassandra-driver>=2.1.1 requirement

Apache 2 licensed; needed for Cassandra support in Ceilometer

> Is the library actively maintained?

This is the official DataStax library and actively maintains it.
https://github.com/datastax/python-driver

> Is the library good code?

Yes.

> Is the library python 3 compatible?

Yes.

> Is the library license compatible?

Yes: Apache2

> Is the library already packaged in the distros we target (Ubuntu latest /
> Fedora latest)?

Packaged by DataStax, and in PyPi.  Not yet in Ubuntu / Fedora.

However, this is only going to be an _optional_ requirement.  If users do not
enable the Cassandra backend for Ceilometer, they will not use it.  As such,
this is a weaker requirement for packaging OpenStack.

Indeed, it would likely be inappropriate to install the Cassandra driver as part
of a default OpenStack distro, as Cassandra is not a primary datastore for any
OpenStack project.

As such, I do not believe we are requiring the distros to package it.  They may
choose to do so for the convenience of their users, but that is their choice.

> Is the function of this library already covered by other libraries in
> global-requirements.txt?

No

commit_message:
Add cassandra-driver>=2.1.1 requirement

Apache 2 licensed; needed for Cassandra support in Ceilometer

> Is the library actively maintained?

This is the official DataStax library and they actively maintain it.
https://github.com/datastax/python-driver

> Is the library good code?

Yes.

> Is the library python 3 compatible?

Yes.

> Is the library license compatible?

Yes: Apache2

> Is the library already packaged in the distros we target (Ubuntu latest /
> Fedora latest)?

Packaged by DataStax, and in PyPi.  Not yet in Ubuntu / Fedora.

However, this is only going to be an _optional_ requirement.  If users do not
enable the Cassandra backend for Ceilometer, they will not use it.  As such,
this is a weaker requirement for packaging OpenStack.

Indeed, it would likely be inappropriate to install the Cassandra driver as part
of a default OpenStack distro, as Cassandra is not a primary datastore for any
OpenStack project.

As such, I do not believe we are requiring the distros to package it.  They may
choose to do so for the convenience of their users, but that is their choice.

> Is the function of this library already covered by other libraries in
> global-requirements.txt?

No

Change-Id: I5803f93be601b875fdfb8276c04e7ecebab8d08e

subject: Guard against concurrent port removal in DVR
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-10-16 01:10:47.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/622ec341b38b1825d69b97e1645f4ddcaf400994', 'message': 'Guard against concurrent port removal in DVR

The delete_csnat_router_interface_ports method is called after
other methods that can yield to send updates
(_remove_interface_by_subnet or _remove_interface_by_port).
During the yield, another API call may delete the port that
delete_csnat_router_interface_ports intends to delete.

This patch verifies that the port db object is actually present
before trying to extract the ID from it.

Closes-Bug: #1381263
Change-Id: Ia371545d641aaa1cbaa0fd10cd233250ec5769e5
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-10-16 05:37:31.000000000', 'files': ['neutron/tests/unit/ml2/test_ml2_plugin.py', 'neutron/db/l3_dvr_db.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/c858b8438939c7e36d0ceced0c0dd6eadc6f5b66', 'message': "Guard against concurrent port removal in DVR

The delete_csnat_router_interface_ports method constructs
a generator expression to retrieve the ports attached
to a router. If a concurrent process manages to delete
one of the ports referenced in the generator from the DB
after it is constructed (but before iteration), some of the
ports will be None objects on iteration.

This patch verifies that the port db object is there
before trying to extract the ID from it.

More details:

This is because the query expression[1] is evaluated immediately
at the time the generator is defined. If there are ports in the
DB at the time of this evaluation, RouterPort objects will be
prepared to be iterated over. However, before the iteration over the
generator happens, something else may delete the port from the DB.
If that happens, when the iteration starts and the 'port' attribute
is accessed on the router port, a SELECT statement will be issued to
the DB to get that port[2] and it will return None.

1. router.attached_ports.filter_by(port_type=DEVICE_OWNER_DVR_SNAT)
2. The RouterPorts table's relationship to the Ports table is using
   the default 'select' lazy loading.

Closes-Bug: #1381263
Change-Id: Ia371545d641aaa1cbaa0fd10cd233250ec5769e5
"}]
commit_message:
Guard against concurrent port removal in DVR

The delete_csnat_router_interface_ports method constructs
a generator expression to retrieve the ports attached
to a router. If a concurrent process manages to delete
one of the ports referenced in the generator from the DB
after it is constructed (but before iteration), some of the
ports will be None objects on iteration.

This patch verifies that the port db object is there
before trying to extract the ID from it.

More details:

This is because the query expression[1] is evaluated immediately
at the time the generator is defined. If there are ports in the
DB at the time of this evaluation, RouterPort objects will be
prepared to be iterated over. However, before the iteration over the
generator happens, something else may delete the port from the DB.
If that happens, when the iteration starts and the 'port' attribute
is accessed on the router port, a SELECT statement will be issued to
the DB to get that port[2] and it will return None.

1. router.attached_ports.filter_by(port_type=DEVICE_OWNER_DVR_SNAT)
2. The RouterPorts table's relationship to the Ports table is using
   the default 'select' lazy loading.

Closes-Bug: #1381263
Change-Id: Ia371545d641aaa1cbaa0fd10cd233250ec5769e5

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-08-27 01:26:41.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/0f394cb8f22fcbb6c08c7d11d0c7ebd32f60b8cd', 'message': 'Remove single occurrence of lost-exception warning

Returning within a finally block can be surprising since the finally
block will "hijack" the regular return flow.  In this case, pylint is
trying to warn us that the return-within-finally would discard the
earlier caught exception.  For this particular function we don't care
that the exception is lost, so the existing code is correct but possibly
confusing.

Our options are:
1. Disable the lost-exception warning for this function

commit_message:
Remove single occurrence of lost-exception warning

Returning within a finally block can be surprising since the finally
block will "hijack" the regular return flow.  In this case, pylint is
trying to warn us that the return-within-finally would discard the
earlier caught exception.  For this particular function we don't care
that the exception is lost, so the existing code is correct but possibly
confusing.

Our options are:
1. Disable the lost-exception warning for this function
2. Rewrite the function to avoid return-within-finally

This change takes approach (2), since the required change is trivial.

This change also enables the corresponding pylint check now that the
only offending case has been removed.

Change-Id: If1706851b4bd67ebdbbdb3485984773598efdf7a
