commit_message:
Using Taskflow to refactor Volume Backup Delete

Refactor the volume backup delete code to use Taskflow
(https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/TaskFlow).
Split volume backup delete code into tasks that perform
the individual required actions to accomplish the pieces
desired outcome. Implementing long-running operations via
task flows is needed, so we can better control the operation
process.
blueprint volume-backup-delete-task-flow

Change-Id: I029313cde65c0700cf714278fcbb99d64da69fc7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder-specs refs/changes/78/104478/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =============================================== Using Taskflow to refactor Volume Backup Delete =============================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/volume-backup-delete-task-flow Using Taskflow to refactor volume backup delete code. .. _taskflow: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/TaskFlow Problem description =================== Split volume backup delete code into tasks that perform the individual required actions to accomplish the pieces desired outcome. Implementing long-running operations via task flows is needed, so we can better control the operation process. .. _engine: http://docs.openstack.org/developer/taskflow/engines.html Proposed change =============== Based on current volume backup delete code, we could split code into the following tasks: 1. Cinder-Api:Split volume backup delete code into three task * CheckAndChangeTaskflow: Check backup status is error or availiable Update backup status to deleting * DeleteCastTask Send rpc message from cinder-api to cinder-backup 2. Cinder-Backup:Split volume backup restore code into three task * ConcreteCheckTask Check volume status and backup status Check volume size and backup size Check whether backup service is up * RestoreBackupTask Do concrete volume date and metadata restore work * StatusUpdateTask Update volume status and backup status 3. Call restore volume backup api flow and manager flow to execute task using taskflow library Related Code changes as follows: 1. Add cinder/backup/flows/api dir to contain api flow and put api flow codes in this dir. 2. Add cinder/backup/flows/mananger dir to contain manager flow and put manager flow codes in this dir. 3. Change existing backup restore code to call api/manager task flow. Data model impact ----------------- N/A REST API impact --------------- N/A Security impact --------------- N/A Notifications impact -------------------- N/A Other end user impact --------------------- N/A Performance Impact ------------------ Other deployer impact --------------------- Developer impact ---------------- N/A Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: ling-yun Work Items ---------- Submit three patches as below to accomplish this refactor goal: 1. Restore volume backup api flow 2. Restore volume backup manager flow 3. Call restore volume backup api flow and manager flow to execute task using taskflow library Dependencies ============ N/A Testing ======= Using current volume backup test case of tempest to verify volume backup restore works well. Documentation Impact ==================== N/A References ========== [1] http://docs.openstack.org/developer/taskflow/ [2] http://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/TaskFlow

commit_message:
Using Taskflow to refactor Volume Backup Restore

Refactor the volume backup restore code to use Taskflow
(https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/TaskFlow).
Split volume backup restore code into tasks that perform
the individual required actions to accomplish the pieces
desired outcome. Implementing long-running operations via
task flows is needed, so we can better control the operation
process.

blueprint volume-backup-restore-task-flow

Change-Id: I20e441ac95cd466ddedb703496beb66fc43f4e70

commit_message:
Cinder volume driver using DRBD

This BluePrint/Spec proposes a new Cinder volume driver,
which uses DRBDmanage to provide replicated storage.

Change-Id: Id02feeac808bb6db585f929c3c06db207bcf23e4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder-specs refs/changes/41/102541/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Cinder volume driver using DRBD ========================================== Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/cinder-drbd-volumes This BluePrint/Spec proposes a new Cinder volume driver, which uses DRBDmanage to provide replicated storage. DRBDmanage itself uses DRBD and (currently) LVM to provide storage. Problem description =================== Currently, there's no vendor-independent, software-only replicated storage available in Cinder. Proposed change =============== LINBIT provides a new Cinder volume driver in a separate python file, which can be activated like any other volume driver. Additional dependencies are * DRBDmanage (http://oss.linbit.com/drbdmanage/) and * DRBD 9 (http://drbd.org), and * dbus (to communicate with the DRBDmanage daemon). DRBD 9 consists of a few userspace binaries[1] and a kernel module[2]; DRBDmanage is a Python library with a command-line interface. The cinder volume driver will talk to the DRBDmanage daemon directly via dbus, it WON'T use the commandline interface. Multiple different configurations (2-way-redundancy, 3-way-redundancy, etc.) can be provided by configuring multiple volume types. As the cinder core is not impacted in any way, all features (eg. snapshots) will work as before[3]; this is a difference to the proposed Replication API, where all layers of Cinder have to know about replication, and where therefore eg. snapshots are currently not available. Alternatives ------------ The volume replication API (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/64026/) [where one solution will use DRBD again]. Data model impact ----------------- None. REST API impact --------------- None. Security impact --------------- None. (Data stored on a Cinder node could be "stolen" on other nodes, too.) Notifications impact -------------------- None. (Should DRBDmanage notify someone if _all_ nodes used for storing one or more volumes become unavailable? Currently it doesn't care if a Cinder node goes down, right?) Other end user impact --------------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ (Nearly) none, to enhanced performance. (Typical DRBD installations measure 1-3% performance overhead; with random-read intensive IO loads and read-balancing in DRBD performance can get _better_.) Other deployer impact --------------------- Dependencies need to be installed; Linux kernel upgrades need matching DRBD kernel modules. Developer impact ---------------- None; feature is optional. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: <philipp.marek@linbit.com> Work Items ---------- https://review.openstack.org/#/c/98983/ Dependencies ============ DRBD 9 kernel module DRBD 9 userspace DRBDmanage dbus Testing ======= Testing will need matching infrastructure. Documentation Impact ==================== See Notifications impact above. References ========== None.

commit_message:
Add blueprint for tag-volume

Add tagging mechanism for the volume object.

blueprint tag-volume

Change-Id: Iaf0f20638b40511290b79f99ac0102cfcda5190f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder-specs refs/changes/05/99305/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ====================================== Allow simple string tagging of volumes ====================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/tag-volume Provide a simple string tagging mechanism for the volume object. Problem description =================== In most popular REST API interfaces, objects in the domain model can be "tagged" with zero or more simple strings, which can be used to group and categorize objects in the domain model. In cinder, we use "metadata" key/value pairs to group and categorize volumes which is a less user-friendly, more complicated way of adding taxonomic abilities to the domain model. In order to align Cinder's REST API with the Internet's common understanding of `resource tagging`_, we can add an API extension that allows normal users to add, remove and list tags for a volume. .. _resource tagging: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tag_(metadata) Proposed change =============== New API functions and corresponding cinder commands will be added. 1. API functions 1) Add a v2 [1] API extension that allows a user to add, remove, and list tags for a volume. 2) Add a v2 [1] API extension to allow searching for volumes based on one or more string tags. 2. Cinder commands Add four commands as follows: cinder volume-tag: set/unset tag on a volume cinder volume-tag-list: list all volume tags cinder volume-tag-show: show tag list on a volume cinder volume-tag-update-all: update all tags on a volume Alternatives ------------ Volume metadata key/value pairs. Data model impact ----------------- Add a new `cinder.db.sqlalchemy.models.TagList` object. The `cinder.db.sqlalchemy.models.Volume` object would have a new `tags` field of type `cinder.db.sqlalchemy.models.TagList` that would be populated on-demand (i.e.not eager-loaded). A tag shall be defined as a Unicode bytestring no longer than 60 bytes in length. For the database schema, the following table constructs would suffice :: CREATE TABLE volume_tags ( resource_id CHAR(32) NOT NULL PRIMARY KEY, tag VARCHAR(80) NOT NULL CHARACTER SET utf8 COLLATION utf8_ci PRIMARY KEY ); REST API impact --------------- 1. Add a v2[1] API extension for retrieving and setting tags against a volume. 2. Add an API extension to allow the searching/listing of volumes based on one or more string tags. The tag CRUD operations API extension would look like the following: Return list of tags for a volume :: GET /v2/{project_id}/volumes/{volume_id}/tags returns :: [ 'tag-one', 'tag-two' ] Replace set of tags on a volume :: POST /v2/{project_id}/volumes/{volume_id}/tags with request payload :: [ 'tag-one', 'tag-three' ] Returns a `200 OK`. If the number of tags exceeds the limit of tags per volume, shall return a `403 Forbidden`. Add a single tag on a Volume :: PUT /v2/{project_id}/volumes/{volume_id}/tags/{tag} Returns `204 No Content`. If the tag already exists, no error is raised, it just returns the `204 No Content` If the number of tags would exceed the per-volume limit, shall return a `403 Forbidden` Remove a single tag on a volume :: DELETE /v2/{project_id}/volumes/{volume_id}/tags/{tag} Returns `204 No Content` upon success. Returns a `404 Not Found` if you attempt to delete a tag that does not exist. Remove all tags on a volume :: DELETE /v2/{project_id}/volumes/{volume_id}/tags Returns `204 No Content`. The API extension that would allow searching/filtering of the `GET /volumes` REST API call would add the following query parameters: * `tag` -- One or more strings that will be used to filter results in an AND expression. * `tag-any` -- One or more strings that will be used to filter results in an OR expression. Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None, though REGEXP-based querying on some fields might be modified to use a faster tag-list filtering query. Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== See `Work Items`_ section below. Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: ling-yun Other contributors: Work Items ---------- Changes would be made, in order, to: 1. Implement REST API 1) add support for CRUD operations on volume tags on the database API layer 2) add tag-list filtering support to `volume_get_all`and `volume_get_all_by_project` on the database API layer 3) add a new TagList object 4) add a tags field of the Volume object 5) the API extension for CRUD operations on the tag list 2. Implement cinder commands cinder volume-tag cinder volume-tag-list cinder volume-tag-show cinder volume-tag-update-all Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= None. Documentation Impact ==================== The cinder API documentation will need to be updated to reflect the REST API changes. The cinder client documentation will need to be updated to reflect the new command. References ========== Mailing list discussions: [1]http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2014-April/033222.html

commit_message:
Added a spec for volume type description change

The purpose of this spec is to address the issue of current volume
type's lacking of information. The spec lays out how to improve
the volume type by adding the description information and
allowing user to find out what is the default volume type.

Change-Id: I6d92cd327b60024ad7f067ddcfc32bf70952f58d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder-specs refs/changes/49/128149/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Volume Type Description ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/volume-type-description (TBD) This blueprint proposes to add the description information for a volume type and allow user to find out what is the default volume type. Volume type description and default volume type can help a user make an informed decision when the user creates a volume. Problem description =================== * Cinder volume types only have abstract names like gold, silver and bronze or whatever the Openstack administrator comes up with. * When a user creates a volume and chooses which volume type to use, currently there are no ways for user to find out what the volume type means. * When a user creates a volume without specifying a volume type, once the volume gets created, the volume type assigned to that volume could be a default volume type or None. User has no way to find out what is the default volume type without looking at the cinder.conf file. Proposed change =============== * When an administrator creates a volume type, allows him/her to enter some descriptions for the volume type. The length of the description should be between 0 - 255. It should be in the form of a string. * Administrator can also update the descriptions of an existing volume type. * User should be able to get all the descriptions of all the volume types. * User should be able to get the descriptions of a volume type. * User should be able to find out what is the default volume type. Alternatives ------------ Noe Data model impact ----------------- Database schema changes: * A new description column will be added to the volume_types table. :: mysql> DESC volume_types; +--------------+--------------+------+-----+---------+-------+ | Field | Type | Null | Key | Default | Extra | +--------------+--------------+------+-----+---------+-------+ | created_at | datetime | YES | | NULL | | | updated_at | datetime | YES | | NULL | | | deleted_at | datetime | YES | | NULL | | | deleted | tinyint(1) | YES | | NULL | | | id | varchar(36) | NO | PRI | NULL | | | name | varchar(255) | YES | | NULL | | | qos_specs_id | varchar(36) | YES | MUL | NULL | | | description | varchar(255) | YES | | NULL | | +--------------+--------------+------+-----+---------+-------+ Database data migration: * Existing volume types will have description empty. REST API impact --------------- * Update "create volume type" REST request to to include description field. * Update "list volume types" REST response to include description field for each volume type * Update "show volume type information" REST response to include description field. * Add "update volume type" REST API to update an existing volume type. * GET /v2/{tenant_id}/types/{volume_type_id} * JSON request schema definition:: 'volume_type': { 'name': 'gold', 'description': 'gold means very important' } * JSON response schema definition:: 'volume_type': { 'created_at': '2013-02-20T08:11:34.000000', 'id': '4b502fcb-1f26-45f8-9fe5-3b9a0a52eaf2', 'name': 'gold', 'description': 'gold means very important', 'qos_specs_id': '4b502fcb-1f26-45f8-9fe5-3b9a0a52eaaa' } * Normal http response code: 200 * Expected error http response code: 400 * Add "get default volume type" REST API * GET /v2/{tenant_id}/types/get_default_volume_type * JSON response schema definition:: 'volume_type': { 'created_at': '2013-02-20T08:11:34.000000', 'id': '4b502fcb-1f26-45f8-9fe5-3b9a0a52eaf2', 'name': 'bronze', 'description': 'bronze means limited storage', 'qos_specs_id': '4b502fcb-1f26-45f8-9fe5-3b9a0a52eaaa' } * Normal http response code: 200 * Expected error http response code: 404 Security impact --------------- create or update volume type description is only allowed for an administrator user. Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- * python-cinderclient will be changed to reflect the API changes. volume_types.create will be updated to include description. volume_types.get_default will be added to show the default volume type. volume_types.update will be added to update the description of the volume type. * Horizon will have corresponding UI changes to deal with the descriptions for a volume type after python-cinderclient implementation. Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: gloria-gu Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- * Implement Cinder API changes. * Implement DB schema changes. * Implement python-cinderclient changes. * Unit Tests. Dependencies ============ Horizon blueprint will depend on this spec: * https://blueprints.launchpad.net/horizon/+spec/volume-type-description (TBD) Testing ======= Updated the unit tests to reflect the API changes. Documentation Impact ==================== * The Cinder API documentation will need to be updated to reflect the API changes. * The cinder client documentation will be need to be updated to reflect the changes. References ========== None

commit_message:
ML2 mechanism driver for Cisco Nexus1000V

Adds the specification for a new ML2 mechanism driver for
Cisco Nexus1000V distributed virtual switch.

Change-Id: I5296496404c88d4bbe7aef49002e18b4ebbca86b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/12/128812/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================================ ML2 Mechanism Driver for Cisco Nexus1000V switch ================================================ https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/ml2-n1kv-mechanism-driver The purpose of this blueprint is to add support for Cisco Nexus1000V switch in OpenStack neutron as a ML2 mechanism driver. Problem Description =================== Cisco Nexus 1000V for KVM is a distributed virtual switch that works with the Linux Kernel-based virtual machine (KVM) open source hypervisor. * Virtual Supervisor Module (VSM): Controller of the Cisco Nexus1000V distributed virtual switch based on Cisco NX-OS software. * Virtual Ethernet Module (VEM): Data plane software installed on the Compute nodes. All VEMs are controlled by VSM. * Network Profiles: Container for one or more networks. VLAN type of network profiles will be supported in the initial version. * Policy Profiles: Policy profiles are the primary mechanism by which network policy is defined and applied to VM ports in a Nexus 1000V system. * VM Network: VM Network refers to a combination of network-segment and policy-profile. It maintains a count of ports that use the above combination. This proposed mechanism driver will interact with the VSM via REST APIs to dynamically configure and manage networking for instances created via OpenStack. Proposed Change =============== The diagram below provides a high level overview of the interactions between Cisco Nexus1000V switch and OpenStack components. Flows:: +--------------------------+ | Neutron Server | | with ML2 Plugin | | | | +------------+ | | N1KV | | | Mechanism | +--------------------+ +-------| | Driver | | | | | +-+--+---------+ REST API | Cisco N1KV | | +---+ | N1KV Client +-----------------+ | | | +-----------+--------------+ | Virtual | | | | Supervisor | | | | Module | | | +--------------------------+ | | | | | N1KV VEM +-----------------+ | | | +--------------------------+ +-+------------------+ | | | | | | +---+ Compute 1 | | | | | | | +--------------------------+ | | | | | | +--------------------------+ | | | N1KV VEM +-------------------+ | +--------------------------+ | | | +-------+ Compute 2 | | | +--------------------------+ The Cisco Nexus1000V mechanism driver will handle all the postcommit events for network, subnets and ports. This data will be used to configure the VSM. VSM and VEM will be responsible for port bring up on the compute nodes. The mechanism driver will initialize a default network profile and a policy profile on the VSM. All networks will have a binding to this default network profile. All ports will have a binding to this default policy profile. Dynamic binding of network and policy profiles will be implemented in the future once extensions are supported for mechanism drivers. Data Model Impact ----------------- This mechanism driver introduces four new tables which are specific to the N1KV mechanism driver. * NetworkProfile: Stores network profile name and type. * N1kvNetworkBinding: Stores the binding between network profile and network. * PolicyProfile: Stores policy profile name and UUID. * N1kvPortBinding: Stores the binding between policy profile and port. A database migration is included to create the tables for these models. No existing models are changed. REST API Impact --------------- None. Security Impact --------------- None. Notifications Impact -------------------- None. Other End User Impact --------------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ The performance of Cisco N1KV ML2 mechanism driver will depend on the responsiveness of the VSM. Other Deployer Impact --------------------- The deployer must provide the following in order to be able to connect to a VSM. * IP address of VSM. * Admin credentials (username and password) to log into VSM. * Add "cisco_n1kv" as a ML2 driver. * Add the "vlan" type driver. * Add the "vxlan" type driver. These should be provided in: /opt/stack/neutron/etc/neutron/plugins/ml2/ml2_conf_cisco.ini Example: [ml2_cisco_n1kv] # N1KV Format. # [N1KV:<IP address of VSM>] # username=<credential username> # password=<credential password> Developer Impact ---------------- None. Community Impact ---------------- This change adds a new mechanism driver for ML2 plugin aligning with the community direction. Alternatives ------------ Alternative is to use the monolithic Nexus1000V plugin. We add this blueprint in order to interoperate with other mechanism drivers and align with community direction. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: <abhraut> Other contributors: <sthillma> Work Items ---------- Work Items can be roughly divided into the following tasks: * Mechanism driver to handle network/subnet/port CRUD requests. * N1KV Client to perform HTTP requests to the VSM. * Unit test cases to test the mechanism driver and client code. * Tempest test cases to peform functional testing. Dependencies ============ Following third party library used: * requests: Requests is a python library for making HTTP requests which is well documented at http://docs.python-requests.org/en/latest/ Link to code -> https://github.com/kennethreitz/requests Testing ======= Tempest Tests ------------- Third party testing will be provided. The Cisco CI will report on all changes affecting this mechanism driver. The testing will run on a setup with an OpenStack deployment connected to a VSM and VEM. Functional Tests ---------------- New functional tests will be added by mocking the VSM responses. API Tests --------- None. Documentation Impact ==================== User Documentation ------------------ Configuration details for this mechanism driver. Developer Documentation ----------------------- None. References ========== http://www.cisco.com/go/nexus1000v

commit_message:
carbonara: fix archive back window

The back window allowed was too large; it should be only 1 block_size
and not 2 block_size.

Change-Id: I44e40ec267761e099a8cb55ac976100e719ed013

added_lines: class BoundLimitedTimeSerie(BoundTimeSerie): def __init__(self, timestamps=None, values=None, timespan=None, timespan_set=None): """Create a bound and limited time serie. This time serie has a limit of retention (timespan) and a limit where you can set the values (timespan_set). """ super(BoundLimitedTimeSerie, self).__init__(timestamps, values, timespan) self.timespan_set = pandas.tseries.frequencies.to_offset(timespan_set) def __eq__(self, other): return (super(BoundLimitedTimeSerie, self).__eq__(other) and self.timespan_set == other.timespan_set) def set_values(self, values, before_truncate_callback=None): if self.timespan_set is not None and len(self.ts): # Check that the smallest timestamp does not go too much back in # time. # TODO(jd) convert keys to timestamp to be sure we can subtract? if (min(map(operator.itemgetter(0), values)) < (self.ts.index[-1] - self.timespan_set)): raise NoDeloreanAvailable super(BoundLimitedTimeSerie, self).set_values(values, before_truncate_callback) @classmethod def from_dict(cls, d): timestamps, values = cls._timestamps_and_values_from_dict(d['values']) return cls(timestamps, values, timespan=d.get('timespan'), timespan_set=d.get('timespan_set')) def to_dict(self): basic = super(BoundLimitedTimeSerie, self).to_dict() basic.update({ 'timespan_set': self._serialize_time_period(self.timespan_set), }) return basic return cls(BoundLimitedTimeSerie(timespan=block_size * 2, timespan_set=block_size), return cls(BoundLimitedTimeSerie.from_dict(d['timeserie']),
deleted_lines: if self.timespan is not None and len(self.ts): # Check that the smallest timestamp does not go too much back in # time. # TODO(jd) convert keys to timestamp to be sure we can subtract? if (min(map(operator.itemgetter(0), values)) < (self.ts.index[-1] - self.timespan)): raise NoDeloreanAvailable return cls(BoundTimeSerie(timespan=block_size * 2), return cls(BoundTimeSerie.from_dict(d['timeserie']),

commit_message:
Explicitly specifies cm_api version in CDH plugin

We set CM_API_VERSION value in cloudera_utils.py, and in function
get_api_client, we add augment version to api_client.ApiResource
whose default value is CM_API_VERSION. Currently this value is set
to 7.

Closes-Bug: #1387960
Change-Id: I54e19c0c39357c410b070df1315ec3a7eb68740d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sahara refs/changes/71/132471/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: CM_API_VERSION = 8 password=CM_DEFAULT_PASSWD, version=CM_API_VERSION)

subject: Reorganize DbTestCase to use provisioning completely
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-07-29 00:16:18.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.db/commit/66952eed006bef6def291d9f39cbdba5a7232e12', 'message': 'Reorganize DbTestCase to use provisioning completely.

This change is the first part in a series of changes
that will allow for full flexibility in database usage
during tests.   The first step is to add more facility
to the oslo.db.sqlalchemy.provision system, implementing
a dispatch system that allows flexibility in creation
and dropping of databases, as well as moving the awareness
of the "openstack_citest" convention into provisioning.
The OpportunisticFixture and OpportunisticTestCase now
fold into DbFixture and DbTestCase, which defers in a simple
way to provision.ProvisionedDatabase for all connectivity.
ProvisionedDatabase in turn decides based on the given
environment as to how an engine should be provisioned
for a given test.

Future changes will allow provisioning to hold onto a single
database engine per test run, as well as allow a single
test class to run in multiple backend scenarios (e.g. one test
against many different backends).

Change-Id: Ifc02505c4c8ebd4a1ca56e14f76c0989576875c3
Partially-Closes-Bug: 1340395

'}, {'number': 18, 'created': '2014-08-11 16:10:35.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.db/commit/4a111183db6ace4b44a113d9dac76b97340f86cc', 'message': 'Reorganize DbTestCase to use provisioning completely

This change is the first part in a series of changes
that will allow for full flexibility in database usage
during tests.   The first step is to add more facility
to the oslo.db.sqlalchemy.provision system, implementing
a dispatch system that allows flexibility in creation
and dropping of databases, as well as moving the awareness
of the "openstack_citest" convention into provisioning.
The OpportunisticFixture and OpportunisticTestCase now
fold into DbFixture and DbTestCase, which defers in a simple
way to provision.ProvisionedDatabase for all connectivity.
ProvisionedDatabase in turn decides based on the given
environment as to how an engine should be provisioned
for a given test.

Future changes will allow provisioning to hold onto a single
database engine per test run, as well as allow a single
test class to run in multiple backend scenarios (e.g. one test
against many different backends).

Change-Id: Ifc02505c4c8ebd4a1ca56e14f76c0989576875c3
Partial-Bug: #1339206

'}, {'number': 25, 'created': '2014-08-22 03:47:25.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.db/commit/f3ba44c62ac708c2f11990d1e1f59dd5f7510f6f', 'message': 'Reorganize DbTestCase to use provisioning completely

This change is the first part in a series of changes
that will allow for full flexibility in database usage
during tests.   The first step is to add more facility
to the oslo.db.sqlalchemy.provision system, implementing
a dispatch system that allows flexibility in creation
and dropping of databases, as well as moving the awareness
of the "openstack_citest" convention into provisioning.
The OpportunisticFixture and OpportunisticTestCase now
fold into DbFixture and DbTestCase, which defers in a simple
way to provision.ProvisionedDatabase for all connectivity.
ProvisionedDatabase in turn decides based on the given
environment as to how an engine should be provisioned
for a given test.

Control of database connectivity remains via the
OS_TEST_DBAPI_ADMIN_CONNECTION environment variable.  When not
set, connectivity defaults to sqlite://, plus those backends
found to be available using "opportunistic" naming conventions.
When the variable is present, it provides a semicolon-delimited
list of URLs, and only those URLs will be used for initial
connectivity.

Future changes will allow provisioning to hold onto a single
database engine per test run, as well as allow a single
test class to run in multiple backend scenarios (e.g. one test
against many different backends).

Change-Id: Ifc02505c4c8ebd4a1ca56e14f76c0989576875c3

commit_message:
Reorganize DbTestCase to use provisioning completely

This change is the first part in a series of changes
that will allow for full flexibility in database usage
during tests.  The first step is to add more facility
to the oslo.db.sqlalchemy.provision system, implementing
a dispatch system that allows flexibility in creation
and dropping of databases, as well as moving the awareness
of the "openstack_citest" convention into provisioning.
The OpportunisticFixture and OpportunisticTestCase now
fold into DbFixture and DbTestCase, which defers in a simple
way to provision.ProvisionedDatabase for all connectivity.
ProvisionedDatabase in turn decides based on the given
environment as to how an engine should be provisioned
for a given test.

Control of database connectivity remains via the
OS_TEST_DBAPI_ADMIN_CONNECTION environment variable.  When not
set, connectivity defaults to sqlite://, plus those backends
found to be available using "opportunistic" naming conventions.
When the variable is present, it provides a semicolon-delimited
list of URLs, and only those URLs will be used for initial
connectivity.

Future changes will allow provisioning to hold onto a single
database engine per test run, as well as allow a single
test class to run in multiple backend scenarios (e.g. one test
against many different backends).

Change-Id: Ifc02505c4c8ebd4a1ca56e14f76c0989576875c3
Partial-Bug: #1339206
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.db refs/changes/70/110170/35 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from sqlalchemy.pool import StaticPool if connection_dict.database is None:
deleted_lines: from sqlalchemy.pool import NullPool, StaticPool engine_args["poolclass"] = NullPool if sql_connection == "sqlite://":

subject: Allow newer versions of pylint
revisions:

commit_message:
Allow newer versions of pylint

The .pylintrc used for neutron refers to checks added in pylint 1.3.0,
and aborts on earlier versions (from a quick experiment).

This change moves from a strict pylint==0.25.2 pin to allow newer
versions, as a first step to moving to pylint>=1.3.0.

Change-Id: Ia293eb1329f2c1c2894ab7d8d2142951e670fbaf
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/requirements refs/changes/13/131013/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Activate pep8 check that _ is imported

Remove the specification in tox.ini that _ is a builtin so that
it will no longer assume that _ does not need to be imported.

This helps ensure that the _ from i18n is used.

Activating this check did not flag any violations.

Change-Id: Idc4d6259d4eb2db66e7122535bc42f8647049a06

subject: Add _wrap_db_error() support to SessionTransaction.commit()
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-09-26 21:28:25.000000000', 'files': ['nova/openstack/common/db/sqlalchemy/session.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/cac6472fd2ad495d22fe6fad89a9485cf025c437', 'message': 'Add _wrap_db_error() support to SessionTransaction.commit()

This patch adds _wrap_db_error() to the commit()
and rollback() methods of sqlalchemy.orm.session.SessionTransaction,
which is the object that is dealt with when one invokes
code of the form "with session.begin():".  The context manager
form does not invoke the commit() method on the
SQLAlchemy Session directly, and instead calls the one
local to the SessionTransaction.

In order to intercept this, we must build a subclass
of SessionTransaction with the appropriate wrapping, and
then patch it into the object that is returned by
Session.begin(), ensuring that it is compatible with
_wrap_db_error().

This whole approach is legacy; newer oslo.db versions
intercept errors at the point at which they occur
via engine events.

Tests are omitted here as we are relying upon the tests
that were added to the corresponding oslo-incubator code.

Closes-bug: #1370191

Change-Id: Ie0456e6daa86c99cf6fbe56ca5dfd8a618f14232
'}]
commit_message:
Add _wrap_db_error() support to SessionTransaction.commit()

This patch adds _wrap_db_error() to the commit()
and rollback() methods of sqlalchemy.orm.session.SessionTransaction,
which is the object that is dealt with when one invokes
code of the form "with session.begin():".  The context manager
form does not invoke the commit() method on the
SQLAlchemy Session directly, and instead calls the one
local to the SessionTransaction.

In order to intercept this, we must build a subclass
of SessionTransaction with the appropriate wrapping, and
then patch it into the object that is returned by
Session.begin(), ensuring that it is compatible with
_wrap_db_error().

This whole approach is legacy; newer oslo.db versions
intercept errors at the point at which they occur
via engine events.

Tests are omitted here as we are relying upon the tests
that were added to the corresponding oslo-incubator code.

Closes-bug: #1370191

Change-Id: Ie0456e6daa86c99cf6fbe56ca5dfd8a618f14232
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/15/124515/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def begin(self, **kw): trans = super(Session, self).begin(**kw) trans.__class__ = SessionTransactionWrapper return trans class SessionTransactionWrapper(sqlalchemy.orm.session.SessionTransaction): @property def bind(self): return self.session.bind @_wrap_db_error def commit(self, *args, **kwargs): return super(SessionTransactionWrapper, self).commit(*args, **kwargs) @_wrap_db_error def rollback(self, *args, **kwargs): return super(SessionTransactionWrapper, self).rollback(*args, **kwargs)

commit_message:
Correct "To create a server" SDK example

"To create a server" SDK example incorrectly used net_id instead of
net.id when assigning the network identifier to a NIC.

Change-Id: Ica993938c57e048f56c03c777ccdebae7ffdedfa
Closes-Bug: #1390347
backport: juno
(cherry picked from commit 404206136c3f155ef90a360338ccbcbe197e7d4a)

Add 'my_ip' option to cinder storage node

I added the 'my_ip' option to cinder.conf for cinder storage
nodes.

commit_message:
Replace trivial instances of tenant for project

This patch replaces the trivial instances were the word tenant is used.
No model is touched yet.

Partially implements: blueprint replace-concept-of-tenants-for-projects

Change-Id: Id21a34d2c414e0497a943ace970584369bd1d83f

commit_message:
neutron-db-manage finds automatically config file

This patch lets oslo.config find config file containing connection
string to database by itself. Config file can be overriden by
--config-file cli parameter as it was before, so it is backward
compatible.

Change-Id: Iacbcd65edfe9ef268a0caf80641e0937a99b06a7
Closes-Bug: 1381100

commit_message:
Fix uninstalled packages for ubuntu

1) bdsmainutils
Fixes heat deployment issues since puppet recipes improperly handle
`hexdump` presence.

Closes-Bug: #1389279

2) bridge-utils
Fixes the absence of `brctl` utility

Change-Id: Idbc1ec089723dfa01d0b91bfc0e2c9771d7805e7

commit_message:
Parametrize headless option for VirtualBox

If you need to start VirtualBox VMs without a GUI, for example, on a
remote computer, you can now set the 'headless' parameter in config.sh
to '1'.

DocImpact
Closes-Bug: #1304345

Change-Id: I868fa67335506a5e048d37411f5d5795b560a338
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-main refs/changes/37/132337/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Set to 1 to run VirtualBox in headless mode headless=0

commit_message:
Add cliff-tablib to requirements

cliff-tablib gives cliff the ability to format list and show output in
html, json, or yaml (http://cliff-tablib.readthedocs.org/). This patch
adds cliff-tablib to requirements.txt so that it can be installed along
with cliff.

Change-Id: I4daab97642482e6f40cd8209ff5edd9c680092c0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-openstackclient refs/changes/46/133246/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Change default keystone auth version to 3 in test/sample.conf
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-10-22 08:51:06.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/dee6e5d8eab09d27bb4da56e389eba1af94f0c0a', 'message': 'Change default keystone auth version to 3 in test/sample.conf

The functional tests devstack gate job currently skips tests
that require keystone v3 API. In conjunction with changes to
devstack [0] this patch will cause the gate job to use keystone
v3 API and stop skipping those tests.

Devstack sets auth version in its /etc/swift/test.conf by
uncommenting the value found in test/sample.conf, so the change
in this patch is sufficient to cause the v3 API to be used.

The devstack patch [0] sets the correct auth url for the v3 API
and creates a fourth test account that is required for the
currently skipped tests to run.

[0] change id I557de01bf196075f2f3adcdf4dd1b43756d8a0ae

commit_message:
Change default keystone auth version to 3 in test/sample.conf

The functional tests devstack gate job currently skips tests
that require keystone v3 API. In conjunction with changes to
devstack [0] this patch will cause the gate job to use keystone
v3 API and stop skipping those tests.

Devstack sets auth version in its /etc/swift/test.conf by
uncommenting the value found in test/sample.conf, so the change
in this patch is sufficient to cause the v3 API to be used.

The devstack patch [0] sets the correct auth url for the v3 API
and creates a fourth test account that is required for the
currently skipped tests to run.

[0] change id I557de01bf196075f2f3adcdf4dd1b43756d8a0ae

Change-Id: I44e159b939f5e3fc3780612823d12262013ea793
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/62/130162/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Pylint Fixes (bad-builtin, bad-indentation, duplicate-key)

Removes the following pylint exceptions and fixes the violations:
 * bad-builtin
 * bad-indentation
 * duplicate-key

This change prefers using all() and any() over allowing indentation
of complex multi-line if statements to match up against the block
that the if statement creates. This was previously solved by
double-indenting in several places.

Change-Id: Ic8705228515d6c07744004d6cf32764cda2611d3

commit_message:
Fix xen plugin to retry on upload failure

The xen plugin does not catch all cases where upload can throw
an exception due to connection failures and timeouts.  This
change extends the try/execpt window to catch these cases.

Also added original connect which in part keeps us from lazy-loading
the connection and logging of exception information so we can
figure out later what happened.

Change-Id: If643a7da9f602ab7bb5d255031a841c674fa6c6f
Fixes-bug: 1378903

commit_message:
Pool Manager - Central/Storage Changes

domains table changes:
- Added 'ERROR' to status column
- Set status column default to 'PENDING'
- Added action column ('CREATE', 'DELETE', 'UPDATE', 'NONE')
  with a default of 'CREATE'

records table changes:
- Added 'ERROR' to status column
- Set status column default to 'PENDING'
- Added serial column with a default of 1
- Added action column ('CREATE', 'DELETE', 'UPDATE', 'NONE')
  with a default of 'CREATE'

Other modifications:
- Modified domain object to reflect new attribute (action)
- Modified record object to reflect new attributes (serial, action)
- Ensured central service continues to work by setting status of
  domain and record to 'ACTIVE'
- Added update_status method to central service

Change-Id: I893f8e7834de4c6ccf3ad587af65a7eee24415b3
Partially-implements: blueprint server-pools-service

commit_message:
Proposal for moving Glance tests to tempest

This proposal intends to discuss the best possible approach
for transitioning some of the Glance functional tests to Tempest.
This also helps continue our efforts for reducing Glance Gap
Coverage in Tempest.

Change-Id: I7c05b3ff43168b3b04f79bcf5b4ad9f37047610f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance-specs refs/changes/46/106146/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Moving tests from glance to tempests ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/glance/+spec/moving-tests-glance-to-tempest Currently, tempest lacks good coverage of tests relating to Glance. We would like to improve some testing in tempest however, that reduces the need for some extra tests which Glance keeps. The purpose of this bp is to introduce the transition of some of tests from Glance to Tempest for:- Problem description =================== None Proposed change =============== Glance funtional tests would be removed from the codebase and moved into Tempest codebase. The transition of tests change would need to happen simultaneously in Glance and Tempest. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ * Glance development tests (or in general called as 'unit tests') would speeden up. Thus reducing the time to run them on locally on developer machines as well as on openstack-ci gates. * Reduction in the likelihood of intermittent failures. * Some of the tests use sqllite database. While adding a new tests, seldom a state comes where multiple tests run into race conditions and intermittently fail. We can try to remove these failure when they are ported onto tempest. Other deployer impact --------------------- * Although, there is no impact on OpenStack users and deployers, there is likelihood of openstack-ci team to introduce some configurations. Developer impact ---------------- * Developers would need to be aware of the tests which are being removed so as to not add tests to Glance codebase, rather work on a tempest Merge Proposition. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: nikhil-komawar Other contributors: TBD Work Items ---------- Breaking down into tasks would need some research on the state of Glance tests and that of the Tempest tests. Dependencies ============ # TODO(nikhil) * Tempest BP needs to be created. * Respective tests need to exist in tempest just before removing them from Glance. Testing ======= Tempest tests are being added as part of this change. Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== * https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Governance/TechnicalCommittee/Glance_Gap_Coverage

commit_message:
Update some options in nova.conf.erb

Update option compute_scheduler_driver to scheduler_driver.
Remove option max_cores since it is not appeared in latest release.

Reference below patch for details
* https://review.openstack.org/#/c/26625/
* https://review.openstack.org/#/c/15068/

Change-Id: I7f98af8225fdcd6864cec21cf1b1fc0cc075356f
Closes-Bug: #1389624

deleted_lines: compute_scheduler_driver=<%= node["openstack"]["compute"]["scheduler"]["scheduler_driver"] %> <%- if /FilterScheduler/.match(node["openstack"]["compute"]["scheduler"]["scheduler_driver"]) or /MultiScheduler/.match(node["openstack"]["compute"]["scheduler"]["scheduler_driver"]) %> # FilterScheduler Only Options<%- elsif /SimpleScheduler/.match(node["openstack"]["compute"]["scheduler"]["scheduler_driver"]) %> # SimpleScheduler Only Options # maximum number of instance cores to allow per host max_cores=<%= node["openstack"]["compute"]["config"]["cpu_allocation_ratio"].to_i * node["cpu"]["total"].to_i %> <%- end %>

Add alarm definition list resource

Change-Id: I232f0d342cd410645cf1f18f88d685f8b7ff1c72
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/monasca-api refs/changes/14/133114/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from urlparse import urlparse helpers.validate_authorization(req, self._default_authorized_roles) tenant_id = helpers.get_tenant_id(req) name = helpers.get_query_name(req) dimensions = helpers.get_query_dimensions(req) result = self._alarm_definition_list(tenant_id, name, dimensions, req.uri) res.body = json.dumps(result, ensure_ascii=False).encode('utf8') res.status = falcon.HTTP_200 def _alarm_definition_list(self, tenant_id, name, dimensions, req_uri): try: alarm_definition_rows = \ self._alarm_definitions_repo.get_alarm_definition_list(tenant_id, name, dimensions) result = [] for alarm_definition_row in alarm_definition_rows: ad = {u'id': alarm_definition_row.id.decode('utf8'), u'name': alarm_definition_row.name.decode("utf8"), u'description': alarm_definition_row.description.decode('utf8'), u'expression': alarm_definition_row.expression.decode('utf8'), u'match_by': alarm_definition_row.match_by.decode('utf8').split(','), u'severity': alarm_definition_row.severity.decode('utf8'), u'actions_enabled': alarm_definition_row.actions_enabled == 1, u'alarm_actions': alarm_definition_row.alarm_actions.decode('utf8').split(','), u'ok_actions': alarm_definition_row.ok_actions.decode('utf8').split(','), u'undetermined_actions': alarm_definition_row.undetermined_actions.decode('utf8').split(',')} helpers.add_links_to_resource(ad, req_uri) result.append(ad) return result except exceptions.RepositoryException as ex: LOG.exception(ex) msg = "".join(ex.message.args) raise falcon.HTTPInternalServerError('Service unavailable', msg) except Exception as ex: LOG.exception(ex) raise falcon.HTTPInternalServerError('Service unavailable', ex)

commit_message:
Increase the 'all' timeout because slow tests are included

The default for tempest in .testr.conf is 500s. This was too short for
the heat slow tests so the time for that was increased to 1200. This
change is to a periodic job so if we need to it can be increased more
in the future.

Change-Id: If27ddef9865c54b997130c707382d2014d82e0a6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/78/131178/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # 'all' includes slow tests OS_TEST_TIMEOUT=1200

commit_message:
Pin nova

Nova a removed a load of deprecated options from nova.conf, we're not
currently using the new options so a temporary pin will allow our CI to
continue which we sort the problem.

Related-Bug: #1390427

commit_message:
Restore python3 tests to safe_encode

The safe_encode function in oslo-incubator contained logic to decode
on python3, which hasn't made it into encodeutils.

Without this logic, things using safe_encode, like cliutils.print_list
in oslo-incubator, mangle output on python3.

Change-Id: If21f1de0e1c0a5fc000328ae403b458b551c02a4
Closes-Bug: #1390505

deleted_lines: return text.encode(encoding, errors) return text.encode(encoding, errors)

subject: Update swift content
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-11-07 15:49:29.000000000', 'files': ['doc/install-guide/object-storage/section_object-storage-install-config-proxy-node.xml', 'doc/install-guide/object-storage/section_swift-example-arch.xml', 'doc/install-guide/ch_swift.xml', 'doc/install-guide/object-storage/section_swift-finalize-installation.xml', 'doc/install-guide/object-storage/section_swift-storage-node.xml', 'doc/glossary/glossary-terms.xml', 'doc/install-guide/object-storage/section_swift-controller-node.xml', 'doc/install-guide/object-storage/section_object-storage-example-install-arch.xml', 'doc/install-guide/object-storage/section_object-storage-install-config-storage-nodes.xml', 'doc/install-guide/ch_basic_environment.xml', 'doc/install-guide/object-storage/section_swift-verify.xml', 'doc/install-guide/object-storage/section_object-storage-verifying-install.xml', 'doc/install-guide/object-storage/section_swift-system-reqs.xml', 'doc/install-guide/object-storage/section_swift-initial-rings.xml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals/commit/e1a2680defa24e88f1f0be6ca4fe371ea86e7a92', 'message': "Update swift content

I updated the swift content in the installation guide as
follows:

1) Consolidated Identity service configuration into proxy
   service configuration section.
2) Changed initial example architecture to install the proxy
   service on the controller node instead of a separate node.
   However, I used wording that supports separate and/or
   multiple proxy services.
3) The steps to configure memcached break installations with
   horizon because the latter references 127.0.0.1 instead
   of the management network interface IP address. After
   consolidating the proxy service to a single instance on
   the controller node, it now references 127.0.0.1.
4) Changed initial example architecture to install two
   storage nodes rather than five storage nodes to reduce
   the barrier to entry for users that want to try swift.
   However, I used wording that supports additional storage
   nodes and also references the swift documentation for
   larger deployments.
5) Changed the initial example architecture to use only the
   management network instead of a separate storage/replication
   network because the original instructions didn't actually use
   the latter. Fully implementing a separate storage/replication
   network requires a considerably more complex configuration
   and eliminating it reduces the barrier to entry for users
   that want to try swift. However, I used wording that
   mentions a separate storage/replication network and also
   references the swift documentation for larger deployments.
6) The Ubuntu and RHEL/CentOS/Fedora packages include ancient
   upstream/example configuration files that contain
   deprecated/defunct options and lack options that enable
   useful features. Packages take a while to fix, so the
   instructions now pull the upstream configuration files.
7) Removed the steps to create disk labels and partitions on
   the storage nodes because a variety of methods exist and
   users should choose their own method.
8) Changed rsync to run as a standard service rather than use
   the xinetd wrapper on RHEL/CentOS/Fedora.
9) Separated account, container, and object ring creation steps
   into separate sections to improve clarity and reduce typos.
10) Reduced partition power from 18 to 10 during ring creation
    because the example architecture shouldn't scale to the higher
    value using the example architecture.
11) Changed storage node service management steps on Ubuntu to
    use 'swift-init' rather than manually starting a large
    number of services.
12) Modified file names and IDs to increase consistency with
    other content in the guide.

I recommend backporting to Juno as this chapter wasn't
functional in time for release. Also, I'm planning to
improve the diagrams in a future patch.

Change-Id: I26710efe16e8cb6ed1a20ebc70b3f6d5962536d1
Partial-Bug: #1389382
Implements: blueprint installation-guide-improvements
backport: juno
(cherry picked from commit ff5ef1b66a039549671ad99efa1de79fd52fc14e)
"}]
commit_message:
Update swift content

I updated the swift content in the installation guide as
follows:

1) Consolidated Identity service configuration into proxy
   service configuration section.
2) Changed initial example architecture to install the proxy
   service on the controller node instead of a separate node.
   However, I used wording that supports separate and/or
   multiple proxy services.
3) The steps to configure memcached break installations with
   horizon because the latter references 127.0.0.1 instead
   of the management network interface IP address. After
   consolidating the proxy service to a single instance on
   the controller node, it now references 127.0.0.1.
4) Changed initial example architecture to install two
   storage nodes rather than five storage nodes to reduce
   the barrier to entry for users that want to try swift.
   However, I used wording that supports additional storage
   nodes and also references the swift documentation for
   larger deployments.
5) Changed the initial example architecture to use only the
   management network instead of a separate storage/replication
   network because the original instructions didn't actually use
   the latter. Fully implementing a separate storage/replication
   network requires a considerably more complex configuration
   and eliminating it reduces the barrier to entry for users
   that want to try swift. However, I used wording that
   mentions a separate storage/replication network and also
   references the swift documentation for larger deployments.
6) The Ubuntu and RHEL/CentOS/Fedora packages include ancient
   upstream/example configuration files that contain
   deprecated/defunct options and lack options that enable
   useful features. Packages take a while to fix, so the
   instructions now pull the upstream configuration files.
7) Removed the steps to create disk labels and partitions on
   the storage nodes because a variety of methods exist and
   users should choose their own method.
8) Changed rsync to run as a standard service rather than use
   the xinetd wrapper on RHEL/CentOS/Fedora.
9) Separated account, container, and object ring creation steps
   into separate sections to improve clarity and reduce typos.
10) Reduced partition power from 18 to 10 during ring creation
    because the example architecture shouldn't scale to the higher
    value using the example architecture.
11) Changed storage node service management steps on Ubuntu to
    use 'swift-init' rather than manually starting a large
    number of services.
12) Modified file names and IDs to increase consistency with
    other content in the guide.

I recommend backporting to Juno as this chapter wasn't
functional in time for release. Also, I'm planning to
improve the diagrams in a future patch.

Change-Id: I26710efe16e8cb6ed1a20ebc70b3f6d5962536d1
Partial-Bug: #1389382
Implements: blueprint installation-guide-improvements
backport: juno
(cherry picked from commit ff5ef1b66a039549671ad99efa1de79fd52fc14e)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/74/133274/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <section xmlns="http://docbook.org/ns/docbook" xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" version="5.0" xml:id="swift-initial-rings"> <title>Create initial rings</title> <para>Before starting the Object Storage services, you must create the initial account, container, and object rings. The ring builder creates configuration files that each node uses to determine and deploy the storage architecture. For simplicity, this guide uses one region and zone with 2^10 (1024) maximum partitions, 3 replicas of each object, and 1 hour minimum time between moving a partition more than once. For Object Storage, a partition indicates a directory on a storage device rather than a conventional partition table. For more information, see the <link xlink:href="http://docs.openstack.org/developer/swift/deployment_guide.html" >Deployment Guide</link>.</para> <section xml:id="swift-initial-rings-account"> <title>Account ring</title> <para>The account server uses the account ring to maintain lists of containers.</para> <procedure> <title>To create the ring</title> <note> <para>Perform these steps on the controller node.</para> </note> <step> <para>Change to the <literal>/etc/swift</literal> directory.</para> </step> <step> <para>Create the base <filename>account.builder</filename> file:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>swift-ring-builder account.builder create 10 3 1</userinput></screen> </step> <step> <para>Add each storage node to the ring:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>swift-ring-builder account.builder \ add r1z1-<replaceable>STORAGE_NODE_MANAGEMENT_INTERFACE_IP_ADDRESS</replaceable>:6002/<replaceable>DEVICE_NAME</replaceable> <replaceable>DEVICE_WEIGHT</replaceable></userinput></screen> <para>Replace <replaceable>STORAGE_NODE_MANAGEMENT_INTERFACE_IP_ADDRESS</replaceable> with the IP address of the management network on the storage node. Replace <replaceable>DEVICE_NAME</replaceable> with a storage device name on the same storage node. For example, using the first storage node in <xref linkend="swift-install-storage-node"/> with the <literal>/dev/sdb1</literal> storage device and weight of 100:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>swift-ring-builder account.builder add r1z1-10.0.0.51:6002/sdb1 100</userinput></screen> <para>Repeat this command for each storage device on each storage node. The example architecture requires four variations of this command.</para> </step> <step> <para>Verify the ring contents:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>swift-ring-builder account.builder</userinput></screen> </step> <step> <para>Rebalance the ring:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>swift-ring-builder account.builder rebalance</userinput></screen> <note> <para>This process can take a while.</para> </note> </step> </procedure> </section> <section xml:id="swift-initial-rings-container"> <title>Container ring</title> <para>The container server uses the container ring to maintain lists of objects. However, it does not track object locations.</para> <procedure> <title>To create the ring</title> <note> <para>Perform these steps on the controller node.</para> </note> <step> <para>Change to the <literal>/etc/swift</literal> directory.</para> </step> <step> <para>Create the base <filename>container.builder</filename> file:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>swift-ring-builder container.builder create 10 3 1</userinput></screen> </step> <step> <para>Add each storage node to the ring:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>swift-ring-builder container.builder \ add r1z1-<replaceable>STORAGE_NODE_MANAGEMENT_INTERFACE_IP_ADDRESS</replaceable>:6001/<replaceable>DEVICE_NAME</replaceable> <replaceable>DEVICE_WEIGHT</replaceable></userinput></screen> <para>Replace <replaceable>STORAGE_NODE_MANAGEMENT_INTERFACE_IP_ADDRESS</replaceable> with the IP address of the management network on the storage node. Replace <replaceable>DEVICE_NAME</replaceable> with a storage device name on the same storage node. For example, using the first storage node in <xref linkend="swift-install-storage-node"/> with the <literal>/dev/sdb1</literal> storage device and weight of 100:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>swift-ring-builder container.builder add r1z1-10.0.0.51:6001/sdb1 100</userinput></screen> <para>Repeat this command for each storage device on each storage node. The example architecture requires four variations of this command.</para> </step> <step> <para>Verify the ring contents:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>swift-ring-builder container.builder</userinput></screen> </step> <step> <para>Rebalance the ring:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>swift-ring-builder container.builder rebalance</userinput></screen> <note> <para>This process can take a while.</para> </note> </step> </procedure> </section> <section xml:id="swift-initial-rings-object"> <title>Object ring</title> <para>The object server uses the object ring to maintain lists of object locations on local devices.</para> <procedure> <title>To create the ring</title> <note> <para>Perform these steps on the controller node.</para> </note> <step> <para>Change to the <literal>/etc/swift</literal> directory.</para> </step> <step> <para>Create the base <filename>object.builder</filename> file:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>swift-ring-builder object.builder create 10 3 1</userinput></screen> </step> <step> <para>Add each storage node to the ring:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>swift-ring-builder object.builder \ add r1z1-<replaceable>STORAGE_NODE_MANAGEMENT_INTERFACE_IP_ADDRESS</replaceable>:6000/<replaceable>DEVICE_NAME</replaceable> <replaceable>DEVICE_WEIGHT</replaceable></userinput></screen> <para>Replace <replaceable>STORAGE_NODE_MANAGEMENT_INTERFACE_IP_ADDRESS</replaceable> with the IP address of the management network on the storage node. Replace <replaceable>DEVICE_NAME</replaceable> with a storage device name on the same storage node. For example, using the first storage node in <xref linkend="swift-install-storage-node"/> with the <literal>/dev/sdb1</literal> storage device and weight of 100:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>swift-ring-builder object.builder add r1z1-10.0.0.51:6000/sdb1 100</userinput></screen> <para>Repeat this command for each storage device on each storage node. The example architecture requires four variations of this command.</para> </step> <step> <para>Verify the ring contents:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>swift-ring-builder object.builder</userinput></screen> </step> <step> <para>Rebalance the ring:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>swift-ring-builder object.builder rebalance</userinput></screen> <note> <para>This process can take a while.</para> </note> </step> </procedure> </section> <section xml:id="swift-initial-rings-distribute"> <title>Distribute ring configuration files</title> <para>Copy the <filename>account.ring.gz</filename>, <filename>container.ring.gz</filename>, and <filename>object.ring.gz</filename> files to the <literal>/etc/swift</literal> directory on each storage node and any additional nodes running the proxy service.</para> </section> </section>

commit_message:
Mount /etc/yum.repos.d from host to storage-repo

We have to mount /etc/yum.repos.d into fuel-storage-repo container if we
want to get latest repos inside containers. Otherwise we will have
latest repos, but they won't be used.

Change-Id: Idf4058a95420ee57183c3c55ac988bdff861c933
Closes-Bug: #1390375
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/21/133221/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: HOST_VOL['repo']="-v /var/www/nailgun:/var/www/nailgun:rw -v /etc/yum.repos.d:/etc/yum.repos.d:rw"

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-11-07 14:46:15.000000000', 'files': ['nova/api/openstack/compute/plugins/v3/multinic.py', 'nova/api/openstack/compute/contrib/multinic.py', 'nova/tests/api/openstack/compute/contrib/test_multinic.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/ad3dd411d35e2617415233fcad141845642b91af', 'message': "Handle NetworkNotFound on addFixedIp API

If passing non-existent network to addFixedIp API, an exception
NetworkNotFoundForUUID happens. However, current API doesn't handle
this case.

This patch makes v2.0/v2.1 API handle this case.
This patch adds NetworkNotFound handling instead of the one of

Change-Id: I3851689e326182c0af2dca11a6b3b3c67d6c9e5b

commit_message:
Handle NetworkNotFound on addFixedIp API

If passing non-existent network to addFixedIp API, an exception
NetworkNotFoundForUUID happens. However, current API doesn't handle
this case.

This patch makes v2.0/v2.1 API handle this case.
This patch adds NetworkNotFound handling instead of the one of
NetworkNotFoundForUUID for readable code and covering additional
exceptions in the future.

Change-Id: I3851689e326182c0af2dca11a6b3b3c67d6c9e5b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/53/133253/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @mock.patch.object(compute.api.API, 'add_fixed_ip', side_effect=exception.NetworkNotFoundForUUID( uuid='3cb9bc59-5699-4588-a4b1-b87f96708bc6')) def test_add_fixed_ip_non_existent_network(self, mock_add_fixed_ip): body = dict(addFixedIp=dict( networkId='3cb9bc59-5699-4588-a4b1-b87f96708bc6')) req = webob.Request.blank( self._get_url() + '/servers/%s/action' % UUID) req.method = 'POST' req.body = jsonutils.dumps(body) req.headers['content-type'] = 'application/json' resp = req.get_response(self.app) self.assertEqual(404, resp.status_int)

commit_message:
Allow jenkins to log into the host as root

The architecture under which beaker is used is that
the jenkins user will run a program that ssh's back
into the host itself. It needs root privs to do this.

If jenkins can already do that, or a different builder
is more appropriate, please let me know.

Change-Id: I5d05edb9d0f3e7a8b32981d7943019bfb5fea04c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/34/131634/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Generate a drop down field for custom heat parameters

If the heat template parameter has a custom constraint of
'nova.flavor', the form will generate a drop down field with a
list of all possible flavors the current user has access to.

Change-Id: Ic4f4baeebc5e8a5fdbf3c3c0f073fed68dd1b114
blueprint: heat-template-choices
Co-Authored-By: Cdric Soulas <cedric.soulas@cloudwatt.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/54/106454/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from django.template.defaultfilters import filesizeformat # noqafrom openstack_dashboard.dashboards.project.images \ import utils as image_utils from openstack_dashboard.dashboards.project.instances \ import utils as instance_utils if custom_type == 'nova.keypair': return self._populate_nova_keypair() if custom_type == 'glance.image': return self._populate_glance_images() if custom_type == 'nova.flavor': return self._populate_nova_flavor() def _populate_nova_keypair(self): keypair_list = [] try: keypairs = api.nova.keypair_list(self.request) keypair_list = [(kp.name, kp.name) for kp in keypairs] except Exception: keypair_list = [] exceptions.handle(self.request, _('Unable to retrieve key pairs.')) if keypair_list: keypair_list.insert(0, ("", _("Select a key pair"))) else: keypair_list = (("", _("No key pairs available")),) return keypair_list def _populate_glance_images(self): images_list = [] images = image_utils.get_available_images(self.request, self.request.user.project_id) images.sort(key=lambda c: c.name) for image in images: image_label = u"{} ({})".format(image.name, filesizeformat(image.size)) images_list.append((image.id, image_label)) if images_list: images_list.insert(0, ("", _("Select Image"))) else: images_list.insert(0, ("", _("No images available"))) return images_list def _populate_nova_flavor(self): flavors = instance_utils.flavor_list(self.request) if flavors: return instance_utils.sort_flavor_list(self.request, flavors) return []

commit_message:
Generate image choices for custom heat constraints

If the heat template parameter has a custom constraint of
'glance.image', the form will generate a drop down field with a
list of all possible images the current user has access to.

Change-Id: I7abc4448c9492056437f7b70a93510882880bee0
blueprint: heat-template-choices
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/56/105856/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from django.template.defaultfilters import filesizeformat # noqafrom openstack_dashboard.dashboards.project.images \ import utils as image_utils if custom_type == 'nova.keypair': return self._populate_nova_keypair() if custom_type == 'glance.image': return self._populate_glance_images() def _populate_nova_keypair(self): keypair_list = [] try: keypairs = api.nova.keypair_list(self.request) keypair_list = [(kp.name, kp.name) for kp in keypairs] except Exception: keypair_list = [] exceptions.handle(self.request, _('Unable to retrieve key pairs.')) if keypair_list: keypair_list.insert(0, ("", _("Select a key pair"))) else: keypair_list = (("", _("No key pairs available")),) return keypair_list def _populate_glance_images(self): images_list = [] images = image_utils.get_available_images(self.request, self.request.user.project_id) images.sort(key=lambda c: c.name) for image in images: image_label = u"{} ({})".format(image.name, filesizeformat(image.size)) images_list.append((image.id, image_label)) if images_list: images_list.insert(0, ("", _("Select Image"))) else: images_list.insert(0, ("", _("No images available"))) return images_list

Generate keypair choices for custom heat constraints

'nova.keypair', the form will generate a drop down field with a

commit_message:
Generate network choices for custom heat constraints

If the heat parameter has a custom contraint of 'neutron.network'.
The form will generate choice field with a list of possible networks
to select from.

Change-Id: Ifd9932465e0c62e0ea2dd3b22531474f8b48c01c
blueprint: heat-template-choices
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/03/92203/14 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if 'CustomConstraint' in param: choices = self._populate_custom_choices( param['CustomConstraint']) field_args['choices'] = choices field = forms.ChoiceField(**field_args) elif 'AllowedValues' in param: def _populate_custom_choices(self, custom_type): if custom_type == 'neutron.network': return self._populate_network_id_choices() return [] def _populate_network_id_choices(self): tenant_id = self.request.user.tenant_id networks = [] try: networks = api.neutron.network_list_for_tenant(self.request, tenant_id) except Exception as e: msg = _('Failed to get network list {0}').format(e.message) LOG.info(msg) messages.error(self.request, msg) return [("", _("No networks available")), ] choices = [] name_template = "{0}{1} ({2})" for n in networks: net_name = n.name + ': ' if n.name else '' choices += [(n.id, name_template.format(net_name, subnet.cidr, subnet.name or subnet.id)) for subnet in n['subnets']] if choices: choices.insert(0, ("", _("Select Network"))) return choices return [("", _("No networks available")), ]
