commit_message:
add the major version: bp/thunderboost

Change-Id: I174bff2a96ff82adb5894a84f33da91417df5b5f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/60/94060/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =============================================================== Accelerate the booting process of a number of virtual machines =============================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/thunderboost The motivation is to speed up the booting procedure for provisioning a (large) number of homogeneous virtual machines. Our work leverage a novel cost-efficient accelerating scheme named VMThunder for deploying large numbers of virtual machines. VMThunder downloads data blocks on demand during the virtual-machine booting process and speeds up the image streaming with a tree-based P2P streaming scheme, so that common image data blocks are cached and reused across nodes. VMThunder has been deployed in the National Supercomputing Centre of China in Tianjin (NSCC-Tianjin) and is published in the IEEE Transactions on Parallel and Distributed Systems (http://www.VMThunder.org/blog/2014/03/02/publication/). This blueprint aims to leverage VMThunder to boost the virtual machine provisioning procedure of Nova. Problem description =================== Currently, end users may experience high latencies when they try to boot up a large number of homogeneous virtual machines. The nova-compute nodes may be too busy to be timely responsive during the deployment phase, yielding long periods of provisioning the virtual machines. This is because of the centralized performance bottlenecks: Before a virtual machine can be started, Openstack either copies the image file through glance, or attaches the volumes through cinder from the backend servers to the nova-compute nodes. In both cases, starting up a large number of virtual machines causes significant workloads on both the servers and the network. Proposed change =============== As discussed above, we aim to leverage the VMThunder tool to provide a new option for starting the virtual machines in Nova. VMThunder downloads data volumes on demand during the booting process of the virtual machines, and speeds up the image streaming. For booting a virtual machine, VMThunder needs two volumes to be ready. These two volumes are called "template volume" and "difference volume", respectively. The template volume is used for reading the shared image content, while the difference volume is used for writing the differences. In order to use these volumes for the virtual machine, on the Nova side, we generate these two volume devices with cinder. VMThunder provides the functionality of creating and destroying the virtual volumes for the virtual machines. Major implementation steps include: 1. We add a new virtual machine-booting choice in Nova that uses VMThunder. Nova currently supports five booting choices: a) name='boot from image', source_type=image, dest_type=local; b) name='boot from snapshot', source_type=snapshot, dest_type=local; c) name='boot from volume', source_type=volume, dest_type=volume; d) name='boot from image(create a new volume)', source_type=image, dest_type= volume; e) name='boot from volume(create a new volume)', source_type=snapshot, dest_type= volume. We need to add one additional booting choice that is backed up by VMThunder: name='boot from VMThunder(create a new volume)', source_type= volume, dest_type=VMThunder. This new choice is triggered by nova command-line client, or from the horizon. 2. We need to add supports for preparing the volume devices for booting up virtual machines via VMThunder. a) Modify the validation method: The method 'from_legacy()' in 'nova/block_device.py' needs to validate the parameters' correctness for VMThunder. We need to add the validation for the VMThunder's booting parameters. b) We need to prepare volume devices for the virtual machines for VMThunder-based booting process during the 'building' step in Nova. b.1) The method 'prep_block_device()' in the file 'nova/compute/manager.py' prepares various volume devices for the virtual machine, depending on users' booting choices. Afterwards, the volumes are mounted to the virtual machines. Therefore, we need to modify this method to prepare volumes for VMThunder. b.2) We need to add one volume-driver class 'DrivervmthunderBlockDevice' in the file 'nova/virt/block_device.py'. This new driver class serves as a proxy that calls the APIs provided by VMThunder to prepare the volume devices. b.3) The 'destroy' method in the file 'nova/compute/manager.py' is called when virtual machines are to be terminated. For correctly destroying one virtual machine, we need to modify this method to call VMThunder's APIs to destroy the volumes corresponding to that virtual machine. Further, on the nova-compute node, a volume device should be available for being used by VMThunder. It will be used as the cache for virtual machines. This volume device can be created in several manners, e.g., a separate hard/SSD disk, or an emulated device with a file directory. Alternatives ------------ (1) Image cache: Nova's image-caching facility reduces the start-up time for repeating the procedure of booting the same kind of virtual machines on one nova-compute node. It does not help for the first-time provisioning. The cache facility is also useless in the cinder-based booting process. (2) P2P transferring: Servers' loads can be decreased by sending the files via the P2P protocol. Each P2P peer not only consumes the file contents, but also uploads to other peers. for example, Wartel et al. use the peer-to-peer (P2P) technology to disseminate virtual machine images, but it takes about 30 minutes to configure 400 servers. VMThunder can perform this task within one minute. (3) Backend storage optimization: The data-transferring process can be avoided with the distributed storage like NFS, cluster FS, distributed FS or SAN. However, the I/O pressure on the storage servers will increase dramatically when booting a large number of homogeneous virtual machines, since the storage backend does not have sufficient replicas to separately answering each booting request. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- Clients' requests should follow the REST message format, by setting the indicator of VMThunder in the existing 'destination_type' field in the message. For example, a REST REQUEST for VMThunder based virtual machines can be: {'server':{'name':'test_virtual VMThunder', ..., block_device_mapping':[{'volume_size':'1', 'volume_id':'72d18614...', 'device_name':'vda', 'source_type':'volume', 'destination_type':'VMThunder', ... Performance Impact ------------------ VMThunder dramatically decreases the latencies of provisioning large numbers of virtual machines, as confirmed from our real-world experiments. Other deployer impact --------------------- Deployer has no impact. VMThunder is triggered passively, as an additional driver for booting virtual machines. Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: vmThunderGroup (PDL) Work Items ---------- VMThunder is written in Python, and is ready for use. Integrating VMThunder to OpenStack is not complicated. So one patch is enough. Dependencies ============ This blueprint needs the support by the VMThunder project. https://launchpad.net/VMThunder. VMThunder is a third-party project that is not currently used by Nova. None of additional libraries are needed. Testing ======= We will add necessary tempest testing into nova's test framework, in order to show the effectiveness of VMThunder. VMThunder is a 3rd party project that accelerates the speed of starting up virtual machines. The unit tests and integrated tests will be added to the component. Documentation Impact ==================== - We need to document how to create VMThunder based virtual machines. - We need to add the documents of how to integrate VMThunder into Nova. References ========== Wiki of VMThunder: http://www.VMThunder.org/ Mailing list: http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2014-April/032883.html Publication:http://www.VMThunder.org/blog/2014/03/02/publication/

commit_message:
Add ODL_NAME variable for OpenDaylight configuration

This makes the name of the unzipped package configurable so you can run
with releases other than the default specified in lib/opendaylight.

Change-Id: Iad879c558d742da03375cb61b0c2ef141573ffec
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/16/133116/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Short name of ODL package ODL_NAME=${ODL_NAME:-distribution-karaf-0.2.0-Helium} local ODLOVSDB=$(cat $ODL_DIR/$ODL_NAME/etc/org.apache.karaf.features.cfg | grep featuresBoot= | grep odl) sed -i '/^featuresBoot=/ s/$/,odl-ovsdb-openstack/' $ODL_DIR/$ODL_NAME/etc/org.apache.karaf.features.cfg local OFLOW13=$(cat $ODL_DIR/$ODL_NAME/etc/custom.properties | grep ^of.version) echo "ovsdb.of.version=1.3" >> $ODL_DIR/$ODL_NAME/etc/custom.properties local L3FWD=$(cat $ODL_DIR/$ODL_NAME/etc/custom.properties | grep ^ovsdb.l3.fwd.enabled) echo "ovsdb.l3.fwd.enabled=yes" >> $ODL_DIR/$ODL_NAME/etc/custom.properties run_process odl-server "cd $ODL_DIR/$ODL_NAME && JAVA_HOME=$JHOME bin/karaf"
deleted_lines: local ODLOVSDB=$(cat $ODL_DIR/distribution-karaf-0.2.0-Helium/etc/org.apache.karaf.features.cfg | grep featuresBoot= | grep odl) sed -i '/^featuresBoot=/ s/$/,odl-ovsdb-openstack/' $ODL_DIR/distribution-karaf-0.2.0-Helium/etc/org.apache.karaf.features.cfg local OFLOW13=$(cat $ODL_DIR/distribution-karaf-0.2.0-Helium/etc/custom.properties | grep ^of.version) echo "ovsdb.of.version=1.3" >> $ODL_DIR/distribution-karaf-0.2.0-Helium/etc/custom.properties local L3FWD=$(cat $ODL_DIR/distribution-karaf-0.2.0-Helium/etc/custom.properties | grep ^ovsdb.l3.fwd.enabled) echo "ovsdb.l3.fwd.enabled=yes" >> $ODL_DIR/distribution-karaf-0.2.0-Helium/etc/custom.properties run_process odl-server "cd $ODL_DIR/distribution-karaf-0.2.0-Helium && JAVA_HOME=$JHOME bin/karaf"

commit_message:
Use 'pg_ctl' utility to start and stop database

Greping output for  starting message don't work all the time
because 'postgres' utility translate messages in other language
depending on computer settings

Change-Id: I6f48db92ccc16e8c75d76dd3fadbbeb9930f9cac
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/89/133189/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: PGSQL_PORT=9823LANGUAGE=C ${PGSQL_PATH}/pg_ctl -w -D ${PGSQL_DATA} -o "-N 100 -F -k ${PGSQL_DATA} -p ${PGSQL_PORT}" start export CEILOMETER_TEST_PGSQL_URL="postgresql:///?host=${PGSQL_DATA}&port=${PGSQL_PORT}&dbname=template1" ret=$? ${PGSQL_PATH}/pg_ctl -w -D ${PGSQL_DATA} -o "-p ${PGSQL_PORT}" stop exit ${ret}
deleted_lines: mkfifo ${PGSQL_DATA}/out ${PGSQL_PATH}/postgres -N 100 -F -k ${PGSQL_DATA} -D ${PGSQL_DATA} -p 9823 &> ${PGSQL_DATA}/out & # Wait for PostgreSQL to start listening to connections wait_for_line "database system is ready to accept connections" ${PGSQL_DATA}/out export CEILOMETER_TEST_PGSQL_URL="postgresql:///?host=${PGSQL_DATA}&port=9823&dbname=template1"

commit_message:
Added hook 'ceph::profile::params::manage_repo'.

Whether we should manage the local repository (true) or depend on what is available (false). Set this to false when you want to manage the the repo by yourself.

Change-Id: I45000830eeb8ea3ffd69c2e4fe4d538360528186

subject: Fix storage.hbase.util.prepare_key() for 32-bits system
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-11-01 06:54:11.000000000', 'files': ['ceilometer/storage/hbase/utils.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer/commit/fa982d1bf5fe6c9657fe4a2c5eb48c65bdac26da', 'message': "Fix storage.hbase.util.prepare_key() for 32-bits system

storage.hbase.utils.timestamp() will return long type object on 32-bits
system, which will cause exception in ceilometer/alarm/storage/impl_hbase.py:
'long' object has no attribute 'encode'.
Then developers on 32-bits system will never get local test passed.

This patch changes type check in prepare_keys() from int to six.integer_types,
which will work for both 32-bits and 64-bits system, python2 and python3
environment.

Note: no test code is added, because jenkins runs on 64-bits system. Reviewers
can download code and verify it on 32-bits system.

Change-Id: I57729ff67efe6d6036fe698e3d86491f9ed4600c
Closes-Bug: #1388181
"}]
commit_message:
Fix storage.hbase.util.prepare_key() for 32-bits system

storage.hbase.utils.timestamp() will return long type object on 32-bits
system, which will cause exception in ceilometer/alarm/storage/impl_hbase.py:
'long' object has no attribute 'encode'.
Then developers on 32-bits system will never get local test passed.

This patch changes type check in prepare_keys() from int to six.integer_types,
which will work for both 32-bits and 64-bits system, python2 and python3
environment.

Note: no test code is added, because jenkins runs on 64-bits system. Reviewers
can download code and verify it on 32-bits system.

Change-Id: I57729ff67efe6d6036fe698e3d86491f9ed4600c
Closes-Bug: #1388181
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/87/132387/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if isinstance(key, six.integer_types):

commit_message:
Use LC_ALL=C in openrc

export LC_ALL=C is required to avoid
'unsupported locale setting' errors then
invoking CLI commands in Ubuntu.

Closes-bug: #1390431

Change-Id: Ie980563025e9938f769ee0e16b629b8cf673d8c7
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobrelia@mirantis.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/19/133219/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: export LC_ALL=C

commit_message:
Excluding alembic migrations from coverage

Currently we cannot tests the migrations within our unit test setup. We
should look into alternative ways of testing migrations and their
coverage.

Change-Id: I5fbc4957a7ed1e0924bce562530adbe5fd2d966b

commit_message:
Correct "To create a server" SDK example

"To create a server" SDK example incorrectly used net_id instead of
net.id when assigning the network identifier to a NIC.

Change-Id: Ica993938c57e048f56c03c777ccdebae7ffdedfa
Closes-Bug: #1390347
backport: juno
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/59/133159/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <programlisting language="python">nics = [{'net-id': net.id}]

commit_message:
Update V3 client for server create list response

This patch updates the client which consumes server create responses
as the server POST response changes from the first server to a list of
all created servers in V3.

The Nova side change is here:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/54214/

DocImpact

Part of blueprint return-all-servers-during-multiple-create

Change-Id: I996dd1a46fd7048fe70e8f460176d0847d78d30a

subject: handle hypervisor_hostname target for live migrate
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-06-19 05:33:12.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/3cf47aab798eacfdcdd7a377b0ec7b87f2a08a41', 'message': 'handle hypervisor_hostname target for live migrate

This change handles the scenario where a user might specify the
hypervisor hostname (long name) as the target host in the live
migrate api call. Currently, the user receives a 400 error
response ComputeServiceUnavailable when specifying "hostname.local"
instead of the expected e.g. "hostname" of the associated service.
The hypervisor hostname seems a reasonable way to specify the
target host of a live migration and users can be confused when
service has short name "hostname" and hypervisor has long name
"hostname.local" having success in one case and an error in other.

In this patch, we catch ComputeServiceUnavailable and check if a
compute node exists with that name. If one exists, we retry the live
migrate api call using the service host associated with the compute
node, else we re-raise.

Change-Id: I8a952f0203617eb5d4314317fb00da67936a524f
Closes-Bug: #1310340

commit_message:
handle hypervisor_hostname target for live migrate

This change handles the scenario where a user might specify the
hypervisor hostname (long name) as the target host in the live
migrate api call. Currently, the user receives a 400 error
response ComputeServiceUnavailable when specifying "hostname.local"
instead of the expected e.g. "hostname" of the associated service.
The hypervisor hostname seems a reasonable way to specify the
target host of a live migration and users can be confused when
service has short name "hostname" and hypervisor has long name
"hostname.local" having success in one case and an error in other.

In this patch, we catch ComputeServiceUnavailable and check if a
compute node exists with that name. If one exists, we retry the live
migrate api call using the service host associated with the compute
node. If no hosts are found, we re-raise. If more than one host is
found, we raise HTTPConflict.

Change-Id: I8a952f0203617eb5d4314317fb00da67936a524f
Closes-Bug: #1310340
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/96/101096/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from nova import objects def _try_live_migrate(self, context, id, instance, block_migration, disk_over_commit, host): try: self.compute_api.live_migrate(context, instance, block_migration, disk_over_commit, host) except exception.ComputeServiceUnavailable: # NOTE(melwitt): retry if the host matches a hypervisor_hostname # to allow users to specify long hostname too nodes = objects.ComputeNodeList.get_by_hypervisor(context, host) if len(nodes) != 1: raise else: host = nodes[0].service.host instance = self.compute_api.get(context, id, want_objects=True) self.compute_api.live_migrate(context, instance, block_migration, disk_over_commit, host) self._try_live_migrate(context, id, instance, block_migration, disk_over_commit, host)

subject: Return all servers from server create V3 API
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-04-28 20:01:23.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/74711f536d448890bebc6507f09095245a4c41c6', 'message': 'Return all servers from server create V3 API

The server create API currently returns only one server (the first)
even when multiple servers are requested. In V3, we can change the
API to return a list of servers.

This change returns a list of servers {"servers": [...]} in the
post response instead of only the first server {"server": {...}}.

DocImpact

Closes-Bug: 1187679

Change-Id: I5c833731f1516c8256f835e21cc22fd613bc57ba
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-04-28 20:01:23.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/b8aca796ed57a05b0ce1d0a496e8e5be78b11398', 'message': 'Return all servers from server create V3 API

The server create API currently returns only one server (the first)
even when multiple servers are requested. In V3, we can change the
API to return a list of servers.

This change returns a list of servers:

{"servers": [...]}

in the post response instead of only the first server:

{"server": {...}}.

It also removes "location" from the response as each server in the
list has links.

DocImpact

Closes-Bug: 1187679

Change-Id: I5c833731f1516c8256f835e21cc22fd613bc57ba

{"server": {...}}.

It also removes "location" from the response as each server in the

Change-Id: I5c833731f1516c8256f835e21cc22fd613bc57ba

commit_message:
Return all servers from server create V3 API

The server create API currently returns only one server (the first)
even when multiple servers are requested. In V3, we can change the
API to return a list of servers.

This change returns a list of servers:

{"servers": [...]}

in the post response instead of only the first server:

{"server": {...}}.

It also removes "location" from the response as each server in the
list has links.

DocImpact

Implements blueprint return-all-servers-during-multiple-create

Change-Id: I5c833731f1516c8256f835e21cc22fd613bc57ba

commit_message:
Just use int(BOOL) to convert to 1 or 0

(This is split out from I24461f4328e188c8983ad574495e11e033ec5ba4 on
neutron, which was a hunt to remove "PRED and A or B" deprecated ternary
idiom.)

int(bool) already returns only 1 or 0 - no need to do our own explicit
version.

Change-Id: I4a26431337f746a9332beb0079e7ddf936253378
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator refs/changes/63/117063/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Configurable /mnt/state

This spec covers making the top level directory where persistent and
stateful data is written to configurable. Currently this top level path
is hardcoded to /mnt/state in our os-apply-config templates,
os-refresh-config scripts, and other element scripts.

Change-Id: Ifdaf31a97a76d69d89c0b5f48714cedfb3cf7b06
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-specs refs/changes/76/94876/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ======================================================= Configurable directory for persistent and stateful data ======================================================= # TODO: file blueprint https://blueprints.launchpad.net/tripleo Problem Description =================== The directory on instances where persistent and stateful data is stored should not be hardcoded to /mnt/state and instead be configurable. This change would allow distros that have a built-in read only root feature to make use of those features as they exist today. In particular, Red Hat style distros offer a read only root feature that is implemented via bind mounts. In this case the stateful path would be configured to be /. A new tripleo-image-element that relied on this feature would take care of creating the configuration files that setup this read only root feature. It's important to realize that this read only root implementation would still take use of a stateful partition mounted at a known location such as /mnt/state. It's different though in that the bind mounts enable you to reconfigure more centrally then in many different configuration files. This implementation is attractive because there is less to reconfigure in individual service's configuration files to re-point all paths to /mnt/state. Configuration files look more similar to upstream versions and well known filesystem paths are still used (such as /var/log, /var/lib). This is friendly to deployers. Proposed Change =============== In order to make the stateful path configurable, all of the hardcoded references to /mnt/state in os-refresh-config scripts would be replaced with an environment variable, $STATEFUL_PATH. $STATEFUL_PATH would be set in an environment.d script that is provided by a specific element that configures the path to the desired location. If /mnt/state is the desired location, a mnt-state element could do the following in os-refresh-config/environment.d/00-set-stateful-path: export STATEFUL_PATH=/mnt/state os-apply-config also needs access to the value set by $STATEFUL_PATH since the path would be used in template config files. The templates themselves would be updated to replace the hardcoded /mnt/state with {{stateful-path}}. The mnt-state element could then install a json file that sets stateful-path equal to /mnt/state. An additional environment.d script in the mnt-state element would modify and export OS_CONFIG_FILES to include this json file. When os-apply-config is run, it will read the value for stateful-path from this json file. Any element that wished to configure the stateful path could configure it in a similar manner. # TODO(slagle) In either case whether /mnt/state is hardcoded or the Fedora style read only root support is desired we are effectively maintaining a list of all stateful/persistent paths. When /mnt/state is used, we have to know all the paths and update them across a set of config files and scripts. When the Fedora support is used, we have to list all the paths and directories in /etc/statetab and /etc/rwtab. It seems like the fedora-state element could just maintain this list on it's own since it is the element that cares about it, but if it is useful to other elements we should instead make it reusable and consumable in some fashion. Alternatives ------------ None come to mind, the point of this spec is to enable an alternative to what's already existing. There may be additional alternatives out there other folks may wish to add support for. Security Impact --------------- None Other End User Impact --------------------- End users using elements that change the stateful path location from /mnt/state to something else will see this change reflected in configuration files and in the directories used for persistent and stateful data. Performance Impact ------------------ None. Other Deployer Impact --------------------- Deployers will be able to choose different elements that may reconfigure the stateful path. The default will remain unchanged however. The mnt-state element could have "stateful-path" in its element-provides and other elements that wish to override that could also provide "stateful-path". This would work the same way as we have multiple elements providing "mysql", and if one of the elements is specified explicitly, that is the one that will get used. Deployers would have to know what the stateful path is, and if it's different across their environment, this could be confusing. However, this seems unlikely as deployers are likely to be standardizing on one set of common elements, distro, etc. Developer Impact ---------------- TripleO developers will have the option of choosing the element they want that provides a stateful-path. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: james-slagle Work Items ---------- tripleo-image-elements ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ * Add a new mnt-state element that configures stateful-path and $STATEFUL_PATH * Update os-apply-config templates to replace /mnt/state with {{stateful-path}} * Update os-refresh-config scripts to replace /mnt/state with $STATEFUL_PATH * Add mnt-state element that sets up /mnt/state as the stateful path * Add redhat-state element that sets up / as the stateful path. Dependencies ============ Testing ======= There is currently no testing that all stateful and persistent data is actually written to a stateful partition. We should like add tempest tests that directly exercise the preserve_ephemeral option, and have tests that check that all stateful data has been preserved across a "nova rebuild". Tempest seems like a reasonable place to add these tests since preserve_ephemeral is a Nova OpenStack feature. Plus, once TripleO CI is running tempest against the deployed OverCloud, we will be testing this feature. Documentation Impact ==================== We should document any new elements and also the Fedora read only root support when available. References ========== Red Hat style read only root support this would enable: https://git.fedorahosted.org/cgit/initscripts.git/tree/systemd/fedora-readonly https://git.fedorahosted.org/cgit/initscripts.git/tree/sysconfig/readonly-root https://git.fedorahosted.org/cgit/initscripts.git/tree/statetab https://git.fedorahosted.org/cgit/initscripts.git/tree/rwtab

commit_message:
Send additional payload as part of delete event

The delete notification currently only includes the resource id.
When ceilometer looks for this event, it expects more metadata
like the ones included in create or update events. This fix
is so we include the necessary payload as part of the delete
event in neutron. There is a test_v2_api.TestNotification
testcase that covers this using mock objects.

Closes-Bug: #1315018

Change-Id: I351e79b741a1b842afc3486c067ce702160a0063

commit_message:
Force run of os-collect-config command on reboot

This enables us to handle cases where we need to assert ephemeral state.

Change-Id: I0f5811a1fe5dc40511acfbc1f1630281bc1914a2
Closes-bug: #1334804
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/os-collect-config refs/changes/11/106111/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: '--successful-run-file', '', '--successful-run-file', '', '--successful-run-file', os.path.join(cache_dir.path, 'os-collect-config-success-file'), '--successful-run-file', '', def test_main_on_first_boot(self): tmpdir = self.useFixture(fixtures.TempDir()) successful_run_file = os.path.join( tmpdir.path, 'os-collect-config-success-file') cache_dir = self.useFixture(fixtures.TempDir()) backup_cache_dir = self.useFixture(fixtures.TempDir()) occ_args = [ 'os-collect-config', '--command', 'foo', '--cachedir', cache_dir.path, '--backup-cachedir', backup_cache_dir.path, '--successful-run-file', '' ] calls = self._fake_popen_call_main(occ_args) self.assertIn('OS_CONFIG_FILES', calls[0]['env']) cfg.CONF.reset() # Call now with successful_run_file, as our system has no metadata # changes occ_args = [ 'os-collect-config', '--command', 'foo', '--cachedir', cache_dir.path, '--backup-cachedir', backup_cache_dir.path, '--successful-run-file', successful_run_file ] calls = self._fake_popen_call_main(occ_args) self.assertIn('OS_CONFIG_FILES', calls[0]['env']) cfg.CONF.reset() calls = self._fake_popen_call_main(occ_args) self.assertEqual(calls, []) # no calls

commit_message:
Validate network config (vlan)

Validate to make sure empty physical networks
are not permitted. Added unit test as well.

Change-Id: Ie55fab3c53276ed48d5e9d603e8c1dc59fa9cc32
Closes-Bug: 1325664

added_lines: physnet_names = self.network_vlan_ranges.keys() if not all(physnet_names): msg = _("physical network name is empty") raise exc.InvalidInput(error_message=msg)
deleted_lines: # TODO(rkukura): Validate that each physical_network name # is neither empty nor too long.

subject: Make L2 DVR Agent start successfully without an active neutron server
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-09-25 01:51:26.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/3e9d2693b68b4948ad514c246ceeecbcf86760a9', 'message': "Attempt to re-initialize DVR flows on failure

When setup_dvr_flows_on_integ_tun_br() fails, for example,
when it cannot obtain a DVR MAC address, we disable distributed
routing for the agent and insert a local flow into the table.

Since the failure could be caused due to a transient RPC
error, change things to retry initialization in the agent's
rpc_loop() code since it might eventually succeed, at which
time we can add all the correct flows into the table.

Change-Id: I5fd9bf4163eafa321c5fca7ffb7901ae289f323b
Closes-bug: #1364215
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-09-25 12:03:02.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/4abf02e94cdf03e9aa841df6fc238235c041dd5e', 'message': "L2 OVS DVR Agent to handle initial dvr rpc failure

If neutron controller is not available, but L2 Agent
was started apriori, the agent was falling back to
operate in non-dvr mode.  This was due to failure
of first rpc from dvr-enabled L2 Agent in obtaining
its unique dvr mac address from the controller.
After that it permanently operates in non-dvr mode.

This fix does two things:
a. We make the l2 agent attempt to settle down in dvr mode
(when configured to operate so) by invoking the dvr rpc
in the main rpc_loop of OVS neutron agent.
When in dvr mode all dvr flows will be configured. When
in non-dvr mode, the fix ensures that basic switching
continues to be functional.

b. We ship the current operating mode of the l2 agent in
report state.  At any point of time agent-show will
let the administrator know if an l2-agent is operating
in dvr mode (or) not.  This operating mode is carried
in 'in_distributed_mode' attribute of agent state and
is apart from the existing enable_distributed_routing
static config that is already sent in report state.

Change-Id: I5fd9bf4163eafa321c5fca7ffb7901ae289f323b
Closes-bug: #1364215
"}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2014-09-26 20:29:21.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/ab38a854e22f0793b8a82804f6a0fdc365d72d63', 'message': "L2 OVS DVR Agent to handle initial dvr rpc failure

"}, {'number': 5, 'created': '2014-09-29 19:19:37.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/685bf7f03d9f0896c1ffb1f39f784d4bccef036f', 'message': "L2 OVS DVR Agent to handle initial dvr rpc failure

If neutron controller is not available, but L2 Agent

operate in non-dvr mode.  This was due to failure

a. We make the l2 agent attempt to settle down in dvr mode

Change-Id: I5fd9bf4163eafa321c5fca7ffb7901ae289f323b
Closes-bug: #1364215
"}, {'number': 6, 'created': '2014-10-01 01:57:03.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/65c3f702a0ac73990b8ce02ae3eef964ac9b774a', 'message': "Change L2 OVS DVR Agent to handle initial DVR RPC failure

If the L2 Agent is started before the neutron controller
is available, it will fail to obtain its unique DVR MAC
address, and fall-back to operate in non-DVR mode
permanently.

This fix does two things:
1. Makes the L2 Agent attempt to retry DVR initialization
(when configured to operate so) by invoking the DVR flow
setup function in the main rpc_loop() of the OVS neutron agent.
When in non-DVR mode, the fix ensures that basic switching
continues to be functional.

2. Correctly obtains the current operating mode of the
L2 Agent in _report_state(), instead of only reporting
the configured state.  This operating mode is carried
in 'in_distributed_mode' attribute of agent state, and
is separate from the existing enable_distributed_routing
static config that is already sent.

Change-Id: I5fd9bf4163eafa321c5fca7ffb7901ae289f323b
Closes-bug: #1364215
"}, {'number': 7, 'created': '2014-10-01 20:47:13.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/7ef353efcc781b4c5243b0b3a25cc1f4e1832873', 'message': "Change L2 OVS DVR Agent to handle initial DVR RPC failure

commit_message:
Make L2 DVR Agent start successfully without an active neutron server

If the L2 Agent is started before the neutron controller
is available, it will fail to obtain its unique DVR MAC
address, and fall-back to operate in non-DVR mode
permanently.

This fix does two things:
1. Makes the L2 Agent attempt to retry obtaining a DVR MAC
address up to five times on initialization, which should be
enough time for RPC to be successful.  On failure, it will
fall back to non-DVR mode, ensuring that basic switching
continues to be functional.

2. Correctly obtains the current operating mode of the
L2 Agent in _report_state(), instead of only reporting
the configured state.  This operating mode is carried
in 'in_distributed_mode' attribute of agent state, and
is separate from the existing enable_distributed_routing
static config that is already sent.

Change-Id: I5fd9bf4163eafa321c5fca7ffb7901ae289f323b
Closes-bug: #1364215
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/11/123911/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Save status in case we need to retry self.dvr_setup = self.dvr_agent.setup_dvr_flows_on_integ_tun_br() self.dvr_setup = False # Initial setup failed, or OVS was restarted if not self.dvr_setup: self.dvr_setup = ( self.dvr_agent.setup_dvr_flows_on_integ_tun_br())

subject: Update swift content
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-11-06 18:13:58.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals/commit/cb67514cc8a31544a2a62d3c549bdb15161294ad', 'message': "Update swift content

I updated the swift content in the installation guide as
follows:

1) Consolidated Identity service configuration into proxy
   service configuration section.
2) Changed initial example architecture to install the proxy
   service on the controller node instead of a separate node.
   However, I used wording that supports separate and/or
   multiple proxy services.
3) The steps to configure memcached break installations with
   horizon because the latter references 127.0.0.1 instead
   of the management network interface IP address. After
   consolidating the proxy service to a single instance on
   the controller node, it now references 127.0.0.1.
4) Changed initial example architecture to install two
   storage nodes rather than five storage nodes to reduce
   the barrier to entry for users that want to try swift.
   However, I used wording that supports additional storage
   nodes and also references the swift documentation for
   larger deployments.
5) Changed the initial example architecture to use only the
   management network instead of a separate storage/replication
   network because the original instructions didn't actually use
   the latter. Fully implementing a separate storage/replication
   network requires a considerably more complex configuration
   and eliminating it reduces the barrier to entry for users
   that want to try swift. However, I used wording that
   mentions a separate storage/replication network and also
   references the swift documentation for larger deployments.
6) The Ubuntu and RHEL/CentOS/Fedora packages include ancient
   upstream/example configuration files that contain
   deprecated/defunct options and lack options that enable
   useful features. Packages take a while to fix, so the
   instructions now pull the upstream configuration files.
7) Removed the steps to create disk labels and partitions on
   the storage nodes because a variety of methods exist and
   users should choose their own method.
8) Changed rsync to run as a standard service rather than use
   the xinetd wrapper on RHEL/CentOS/Fedora.
9) Separated account, container, and object ring creation steps
   into separate sections to improve clarity and reduce typos.
10) Reduced partition power from 18 to 10 during ring creation
    because the example architecture shouldn't scale to the higher
    value using the example architecture.
11) Changed storage node service management steps on Ubuntu to
    use 'swift-init' rather than manually starting a large
    number of services.
12) Modified file names and IDs to increase consistency with
    other content in the guide.

I recommend backporting to Juno as this chapter wasn't
functional in time for release. Also, I'm planning to
improve the diagrams in a future patch.

Change-Id: I26710efe16e8cb6ed1a20ebc70b3f6d5962536d1
Partial-Bug: #1389382
Implements: blueprint installation-guide-improvements
backport: juno

commit_message:
Update swift content

I updated the swift content in the installation guide as
follows:

1) Consolidated Identity service configuration into proxy
   service configuration section.
2) Changed initial example architecture to install the proxy
   service on the controller node instead of a separate node.
   However, I used wording that supports separate and/or
   multiple proxy services.
3) The steps to configure memcached break installations with
   horizon because the latter references 127.0.0.1 instead
   of the management network interface IP address. After
   consolidating the proxy service to a single instance on
   the controller node, it now references 127.0.0.1.
4) Changed initial example architecture to install two
   storage nodes rather than five storage nodes to reduce
   the barrier to entry for users that want to try swift.
   However, I used wording that supports additional storage
   nodes and also references the swift documentation for
   larger deployments.
5) Changed the initial example architecture to use only the
   management network instead of a separate storage/replication
   network because the original instructions didn't actually use
   the latter. Fully implementing a separate storage/replication
   network requires a considerably more complex configuration
   and eliminating it reduces the barrier to entry for users
   that want to try swift. However, I used wording that
   mentions a separate storage/replication network and also
   references the swift documentation for larger deployments.
6) The Ubuntu and RHEL/CentOS/Fedora packages include ancient
   upstream/example configuration files that contain
   deprecated/defunct options and lack options that enable
   useful features. Packages take a while to fix, so the
   instructions now pull the upstream configuration files.
7) Removed the steps to create disk labels and partitions on
   the storage nodes because a variety of methods exist and
   users should choose their own method.
8) Changed rsync to run as a standard service rather than use
   the xinetd wrapper on RHEL/CentOS/Fedora.
9) Separated account, container, and object ring creation steps
   into separate sections to improve clarity and reduce typos.
10) Reduced partition power from 18 to 10 during ring creation
    because the example architecture shouldn't scale to the higher
    value using the example architecture.
11) Changed storage node service management steps on Ubuntu to
    use 'swift-init' rather than manually starting a large
    number of services.
12) Modified file names and IDs to increase consistency with
    other content in the guide.

I recommend backporting to Juno as this chapter wasn't
functional in time for release. Also, I'm planning to
improve the diagrams in a future patch.

Change-Id: I26710efe16e8cb6ed1a20ebc70b3f6d5962536d1
Partial-Bug: #1389382
Implements: blueprint installation-guide-improvements
backport: juno
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/05/133105/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <section xmlns="http://docbook.org/ns/docbook" xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" version="5.0" xml:id="swift-initial-rings"> <title>Create initial rings</title> <para>Before starting the Object Storage services, you must create the initial account, container, and object rings. The ring builder creates configuration files that each node uses to determine and deploy the storage architecture. For simplicity, this guide uses one region and zone with 2^10 (1024) maximum partitions, 3 replicas of each object, and 1 hour minimum time between moving a partition more than once. For Object Storage, a partition indicates a directory on a storage device rather than a conventional partition table. For more information, see the <link xlink:href="http://docs.openstack.org/developer/swift/deployment_guide.html" >Deployment Guide</link>.</para> <section xml:id="swift-initial-rings-account"> <title>Account ring</title> <para>The account server uses the account ring to maintain lists of containers.</para> <procedure> <title>To create the ring</title> <note> <para>Perform these steps on the controller node.</para> </note> <step> <para>Change to the <literal>/etc/swift</literal> directory.</para> </step> <step> <para>Create the base <filename>account.builder</filename> file:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>swift-ring-builder account.builder create 10 3 1</userinput></screen> </step> <step> <para>Add each storage node to the ring:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>swift-ring-builder account.builder \ add r1z1-<replaceable>STORAGE_NODE_MANAGEMENT_INTERFACE_IP_ADDRESS</replaceable>:6002/<replaceable>DEVICE_NAME</replaceable> <replaceable>DEVICE_WEIGHT</replaceable></userinput></screen> <para>Replace <replaceable>STORAGE_NODE_MANAGEMENT_INTERFACE_IP_ADDRESS</replaceable> with the IP addess of the management network on the storage node. Replace <replaceable>DEVICE_NAME</replaceable> with a storage device name on the same storage node. For example, using the first storage node in <xref linkend="swift-install-storage-node"/> with the <literal>/dev/sdb1</literal> storage device and weight of 100:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>swift-ring-builder account.builder add r1z1-10.0.0.51:6002/sdb1 100</userinput></screen> <para>Repeat this command for each storage device on each storage node. The example architecture requires four variations of this command.</para> </step> <step> <para>Verify the ring contents:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>swift-ring-builder account.builder</userinput></screen> </step> <step> <para>Rebalance the ring:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>swift-ring-builder account.builder rebalance</userinput></screen> <note> <para>This process can take a while.</para> </note> </step> </procedure> </section> <section xml:id="swift-initial-rings-container"> <title>Container ring</title> <para>The container server uses the container ring to maintain lists of objects. However, it does not track object locations.</para> <procedure> <title>To create the ring</title> <note> <para>Perform these steps on the controller node.</para> </note> <step> <para>Change to the <literal>/etc/swift</literal> directory.</para> </step> <step> <para>Create the base <filename>container.builder</filename> file:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>swift-ring-builder container.builder create 10 3 1</userinput></screen> </step> <step> <para>Add each storage node to the ring:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>swift-ring-builder container.builder \ add r1z1-<replaceable>STORAGE_NODE_MANAGEMENT_INTERFACE_IP_ADDRESS</replaceable>:6001/<replaceable>DEVICE_NAME</replaceable> <replaceable>DEVICE_WEIGHT</replaceable></userinput></screen> <para>Replace <replaceable>STORAGE_NODE_MANAGEMENT_INTERFACE_IP_ADDRESS</replaceable> with the IP addess of the management network on the storage node. Replace <replaceable>DEVICE_NAME</replaceable> with a storage device name on the same storage node. For example, using the first storage node in <xref linkend="swift-install-storage-node"/> with the <literal>/dev/sdb1</literal> storage device and weight of 100:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>swift-ring-builder container.builder add r1z1-10.0.0.51:6001/sdb1 100</userinput></screen> <para>Repeat this command for each storage device on each storage node. The example architecture requires four variations of this command.</para> </step> <step> <para>Verify the ring contents:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>swift-ring-builder container.builder</userinput></screen> </step> <step> <para>Rebalance the ring:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>swift-ring-builder container.builder rebalance</userinput></screen> <note> <para>This process can take a while.</para> </note> </step> </procedure> </section> <section xml:id="swift-initial-rings-object"> <title>Object ring</title> <para>The object server uses the object ring to maintain lists of object locations on local devices.</para> <procedure> <title>To create the ring</title> <note> <para>Perform these steps on the controller node.</para> </note> <step> <para>Change to the <literal>/etc/swift</literal> directory.</para> </step> <step> <para>Create the base <filename>object.builder</filename> file:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>swift-ring-builder object.builder create 10 3 1</userinput></screen> </step> <step> <para>Add each storage node to the ring:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>swift-ring-builder object.builder \ add r1z1-<replaceable>STORAGE_NODE_MANAGEMENT_INTERFACE_IP_ADDRESS</replaceable>:6000/<replaceable>DEVICE_NAME</replaceable> <replaceable>DEVICE_WEIGHT</replaceable></userinput></screen> <para>Replace <replaceable>STORAGE_NODE_MANAGEMENT_INTERFACE_IP_ADDRESS</replaceable> with the IP addess of the management network on the storage node. Replace <replaceable>DEVICE_NAME</replaceable> with a storage device name on the same storage node. For example, using the first storage node in <xref linkend="swift-install-storage-node"/> with the <literal>/dev/sdb1</literal> storage device and weight of 100:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>swift-ring-builder object.builder add r1z1-10.0.0.51:6000/sdb1 100</userinput></screen> <para>Repeat this command for each storage device on each storage node. The example architecture requires four variations of this command.</para> </step> <step> <para>Verify the ring contents:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>swift-ring-builder object.builder</userinput></screen> </step> <step> <para>Rebalance the ring:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>swift-ring-builder object.builder rebalance</userinput></screen> <note> <para>This process can take a while.</para> </note> </step> </procedure> </section> <section xml:id="swift-initial-rings-distribute"> <title>Distribute ring configuration files</title> <para>Copy the <filename>account.ring.gz</filename>, <filename>container.ring.gz</filename>, and <filename>object.ring.gz</filename> files to the <literal>/etc/swift</literal> directory on each storage node and any additional nodes running the proxy service.</para> </section> </section>

  be changed according to stored in cluster attributes

commit_message:
Mount /etc/yum.repos.d from host to storage-repo

We have to mount /etc/yum.repos.d into fuel-storage-repo container if we
want to get latest repos inside containers. Otherwise we will have
latest repos, but they won't be used.

Change-Id: I66178d44ed667e56293093d9c91c71c540a86069
Closes-Bug: #1390375

(cherry picked from commit f43179a544b2e8a628c7fff99d20daf603cdfa47)

commit_message:
Add a new driver to support AMT as power driver

Introduce a new driver pxe_amttool to extend ironic's range to Desktop.
AMT/vPro is widely used in Desktop to remotely control the power,
similar like IPMI.
It will use amttool as power management and pxe as deploy management.

Change-Id: Id720628adcd4b8b2bc503c2ac44278143d657271
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs refs/changes/36/133136/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== AMT PXE Driver ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ironic/+spec/amt-pxe-driver This blueprint implements a new driver -- "PXEAndAMTToolDriver" which supports deployment for AMT/vPro system on Desktops. Problem description =================== Currently there is no support with Ironic to do deployment for Desktops within AMT/vPro system. This BP will extend Ironic to Desktop area. Proposed change =============== Implements a new driver -- "PXEAndAMTToolDriver" -- that uses amttool to control the power of Desktops with AMT System and uses pxe to deliver the image to Desktops. Following are details, * Add new class PXEAndAMTToolDriver inherited from base.BaseDriver in ironic/drivers/pxe.py * Add new class AMTPower inherited from base.PowerInterface in ironic/drivers/modules/amttool.py - ``validate()`` - Validata the node driver info - ``get_power_state()`` - Get the power state from the node - ``set_power_state()`` - Set the power state of the node, such as power on/off - ``reboot()`` - reboot the node * Add new class AMTMangement inherited from base.ManagementInterface in ironic/drivers/modules/amttool.py - ``set_boot_device()`` - Set the boot device of the node - ``get_boot_device()`` - Get the boot device of the node Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None RPC API impact -------------- None Driver API impact ----------------- None Nova driver impact ------------------ None Security impact --------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Scalability impact ------------------ None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- Additionally three fileds need to be provided with driver_info * ``amt_address`` - node's IP address to connect to. * ``amt_password`` - node's password * ``amt_boot_device`` - amt needs to set boot_device everytime. Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: tan-lin-good Work Items ---------- Implement ``PXEAndAMTToolDriver`` class inherited from ``base.BaseDriver``. Implement ``AMTPower`` class inherited from ``base.PowerInterface`` Implement ``AMTManagement`` class inherited from ``base.managementInterface`` Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Will add Uit Testing. Upgrades and Backwards Compatibility ==================================== None Documentation Impact ==================== Will document the usage of this driver. References ========== None

commit_message:
Mount /etc/yum.repos.d from host to storage-repo

We have to mount /etc/yum.repos.d into fuel-storage-repo container if we
want to get latest repos inside containers. Otherwise we will have
latest repos, but they won't be used.

Change-Id: I7de729be3cb17cb13d1838b69fb964cb43248cff
Closes-Bug: #1390375

commit_message:
Mount /etc/yum.repos.d from host to storage-repo

We have to mount /etc/yum.repos.d into fuel-storage-repo container if we
want to get latest repos inside containers. Otherwise we will have
latest repos, but they won't be used.

Change-Id: I66178d44ed667e56293093d9c91c71c540a86069
Closes-Bug: #1390375

commit_message:
Decrease number of retries for puppet deployments

Default behavior before: 3 puppet runs for the
current role on the current node: 1 run + 2 retries

Now we will run only 2 times: 1 run + 1 retries

In 99 out of 100 cases, if the problem persists
when we restart puppet, it will not disappear after
next restart. That's why it makes no sense to run
more than 2 times. Thus we save time, follow the
ideology of 'fail fast', speed up deployment
process, show user more detailed message about
problem instead of 'deployment timeout'.

commit_message:
I18n

Keystoneclient didn't provide translated messages. With this
change, the messages are marked for translation.

DocImpact

Implements: blueprint keystoneclient-i18n

Change-Id: I85263a71671a1dffed524185266e6bb7ae559630

The "L" is for "log" and the other letter comes from # the level. _LI = _translators.log_info _LW = _translators.log_warning _LE = _translators.log_error _LC = _translators.log_critical

subject: Ability to flag projects to use non-standard libraries
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-10-21 19:42:03.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack-gate/commit/e0027ac3f34baf0cdfd9e45a562270a4ee7c0642', 'message': 'Ability to flag projects to use non-standard libraries

Several jobs run requirements/update.py to check if the listed
requirements are present in the global requirements file. In the
update.py there is a capability to switch failure to a warning
if there is an environment flag NON_STANDARD_REQS introduced in
Id90547e2fb0a5736385c9f31ba386e7c2e0616df

In this review, we make sure that if the flag is specified in
the project yml file (example in
I1fb4d58a36c9a12f87527f4fb551f4b664c386bd ) then we pass that
flag long to stack.sh.

Change-Id: I32a2cd1245a6fad373870362d3399cf1397aa7f1
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-10-27 21:02:37.000000000', 'files': ['devstack-vm-gate.sh', 'devstack-vm-gate-wrap.sh'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack-gate/commit/2574e518651f8d6fe6a74a88377601ebc28887f2', 'message': "Ability to flag projects to use non-standard libraries

devstack and requirements repo are being updated in the
following changes to allow projects to specify a soft
dependency for additional libraries not specified in
global-requirements. In this review, we enable a project
to specify the flag in a project/job's yml file and
pass the flag along down to devstack

Depends-On: I4aa606514131b5dde67d87f5c8db5a3f3e50fc03

Change-Id: I32a2cd1245a6fad373870362d3399cf1397aa7f1
"}]
commit_message:
Ability to flag projects to use non-standard libraries

devstack and requirements repo are being updated in the
following changes to allow projects to specify a soft
dependency for additional libraries not specified in
global-requirements. In this review, we enable a project
to specify the flag in a project/job's yml file and
pass the flag along down to devstack

Depends-On: I4aa606514131b5dde67d87f5c8db5a3f3e50fc03
Depends-On: I1f195ef9ff1509659848e14ec9936ff6f66a6496

Change-Id: I32a2cd1245a6fad373870362d3399cf1397aa7f1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack-gate refs/changes/18/130018/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Set to 1 if running the project is using libraries not specified # in global requirements export NON_STANDARD_REQS=${NON_STANDARD_REQS:-0}

commit_message:
Controls improvements

 - proper selection classes
 - css hacks removal
 - removed default 'enable-selection' class - it should be added on demand per each element

Change-Id: I9ca621d671288fe0f7d8281db5fdf0275eb1eb48
Closes-bug: #1386622

subject: Have resource CRUD return self to simplify the proxies
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-11-01 19:50:35.000000000', 'files': ['openstack/resource.py', 'openstack/tests/test_resource.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstacksdk/commit/2f1b4086da53dd97f61aa6a9adbfab9f1d50446f', 'message': 'Have resource CRUD return self to simplify the proxies

Instead of:
    def create_project(self, **data):
        obj = project.Project(**data)
        obj.create(self.session)
        return obj

We can:
    def create_project(self, **data):
        return project.Project(**data).create(self.session)

Change-Id: Ifbb41c7d1de461c80ea98b2c3d2e715da770a07f
'}]

added_lines: self.assertEqual(obj, obj.get(self.session)) self.assertEqual(obj, obj.create(self.session)) self.assertEqual(obj, obj.create(self.session)) self.assertEqual(obj, obj.update(self.session))

commit_message:
Add CERT file support in heat-keystone-setup-domain

Add below options to support ssl connection.
--insecure
--os-cacert
--os-cert
--os-key

Change-Id: I9d1fd07df783d7410ac3f51b5d4e8434d57182a4

commit_message:
Specify TEMPEST_VOLUME_DRIVER for ceph

This option doesn't do anything in itself other than allow
TEMPEST_STORAGE_PROTOCOL to be set.

commit_message:
Add wait for async secgroup add to minimum basic scenario

Security group add actions are asynchronous so we can't assume that
the security will be available immediately to ssh into the server.
This commit fixes the issue by adding a wait for the secgroup to show
up in the server before we move on.

Fixes-bug: 1390355
Change-Id: Idd561d77ce2e4b83421bb7bfb6327a6c940b62ed

commit_message:
Add volume driver for Huawei 18000 storage system

Huawei OceanStor 18000-series enterprise storage system is an optimum
storage platform for next-generation data centers that feature
virtualization, hybrid cloud, simplified IT, and low carbon footprints.

This patch add an iSCSI driver and a FC driver for Huawei 18000 storage
system, using REST. We define a common module for both iSCSI driver and
FC driver.

Implements: blueprint huawei-18000-driver
Change-Id: Ied3ba32589ed78d233a588f6bcdb1cfb766449c8

commit_message:
Auto generate the API documentation

Once we use the pbr based build to generate files, we prune
the indexes to remove references to code we would like to
hide like the common modules and private modules in conf.py.
We reuse the same excluded_patterns variable that is already
used in Sphinx and filter these modules from autoindex.rst

Change-Id: I21e516a80f20eb2d5965a5a63c7dfd2d231c67e1

commit_message:
Add the StorPool volume driver proposal.

Change-Id: I192a2fba7996d6d5991fa6af4bd6d53c99c9a2ba
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder-specs refs/changes/14/115714/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== StorPool Volume (Block Device) Driver ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/storpool-block-driver There are various Cinder volume drivers providing access to network-attached storage, such as GlusterFS, NFS, RBD, etc. The purpose of this blueprint is to add a driver supporting the volumes defined in a StorPool cluster. Problem description =================== StorPool is distributed data storage software running on standard x86 servers. StorPool aggregates the performance and capacity of all drives into a shared pool of storage distributed among the servers. Within this storage pool the user creates thin-provisioned volumes that are exposed to the clients as block devices. StorPool consists of two parts wrapped in one package - a server and a client. The StorPool server allows a hypervisor to act as a storage node, while the StorPool client allows a hypervisor node to access the storage pool and act as a compute node. In OpenStack terms the StorPool solution allows each hypervisor node to be both a storage and a compute node simultaneously. Proposed change =============== The proposed driver will make use of the StorPool API (based on JSON over HTTP) to query, manage and attach volumes defined in the StorPool cluster. It will include all the features required by the Juno release. Alternatives ------------ None. Data model impact ----------------- None. REST API impact --------------- None. Security impact --------------- None. Notifications impact -------------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ Certain volume-related operations will need to be synchronized and possibly executed one at a time. Other deployer impact --------------------- None. Developer impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Peter Penchev <openstack-dev@storpool.com> Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- * Write the driver. * Write unit tests. * Provide certification tests. * Provide a CI setup. Dependencies ============ The StorPool driver for Nova for handling attaching and detaching of StorPool volumes: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/libvirt-storpool-volume-attach Testing ======= Since the test setup requires an operational StorPool cluster, the unit tests will mostly use mocking to simulate the operations. A separate continuous integration environment will be set up by StorPool and access to it will be provided for running automated CI tests. Documentation Impact ==================== Using the StorPool driver will be documented. References ========== The StorPool distributed storage software: http://storpool.com/

commit_message:
Magnum - OpenStack Containers Service

OpenStack project for development of a new service for using
advanced features of containers in combination with Nova.

NOTE: At the Design summit session, Nova core guidance was
to start a a new project in stackforge and evaluate later
(next summit) if this needs to be under Nova Umbrella.

Co-Authored-By: Davanum Srinivas <davanum@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I70763a48adbd93ef920885398a03d7f6b36f7c11
